revision.text:
{{Infobox film festival | name = 24/7 Film Festival | logo = 24 7 Youth Film Festival Logo.jpg | logo_alt = The logo for the 24/7 Youth Film Festival. The image background is white. Along the top run "24" and "7" with a dotted line between them. Running up the right side of the image is the phrase "Youth film festival" | logo_size = | image = | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = 24 7 Youth Film Festival Logo from 2008 | opening = | closing = | location = [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]] | telephone = | founded = 2002 | awardsreceived = Local Government Cultural Award (2005) | awards = | films = | directors = | producers = | writers = | starring = | host = | number = | date = | language = | website = http://www.247youthfilmfestival.com.au/ | chronology = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
The '''24/7 Film Festival''' is an annual amateur film festival in held in the [[Mosman, New South Wales|Mosman]], [[Manly, New South Wales|Manly]], [[Warringah Council]] and [[Pittwater Council]] area, all northern suburbs of [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]]. First held in 2002, the Council-sponsored event consists of a challenge to 12- to 24-year-olds to produce a 7-minute film in 24 hours. The festival also consists of film workshops and is crowned by the showing and judging of the entries, held at various local cinemas.<ref>[http://www.pittwater.nsw.gov.au/community/youth/247_youth_film_festival 24/7 Youth Film Festival] (from the [[Pittwater Council]] website)</ref>
In 2005 the festival won a local government cultural award for leadership in cultural programs and projects.<ref>''[http://www.warringah.nsw.gov.au/wcadmin/Portals/0/Module368_Item197/Published/Film%20Makers%20approved.pdf Calling young film makers]'' - [[Warringah Council]] media release, Wednesday 26 July 2006</ref>
==Item List== A list of 'items' is published each year at the commencement of the competition. It is required that an item from each of the 4 categories appears in each film and that a total of at least 5 items are used. This is to ensure that films were made specifically for the competition and were made in the 24-hour period designated. The four categories are Locations, Concepts, Lines of Dialogue and Objects.
A "Secret Rule" is announced each year at the same time, placing some extra restriction on films to further ensure adherence to the time constraint. The rules for 2006 and 2007 have been to have a line of dialogue in a language other than English, and to have two characters say a line of dialogue at the same time, respectively.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://sydneyhotshots.com/services/hens-night/| title=hens night sydney }} Saturday, 3 December 2016 </ref>
==Rules== * All films must be made in the 24-hour period specified. * All films must be no more than 7 minutes in length. * All films must incorporate at least 5 of the items detailed on the official list of 12 items, including at least 1 from each category. * All participants must be no older than 24 years and no younger than 12 years at the time of competition. * All films must be viewable by a public audience (rating of M or less [[Office of Film and Literature Classification (Australia)|Australian Bureau of Classification]]). * Any film teams partaking in unlawful or anti-social behaviour (including '[[Jackass (TV series)|Jackass]]' style filmmaking) in or around the 24-hour period will be immediately disqualified. * Participants must not incorporate copyrighted music into their films. * The filmmakers must have the permission of all actors/extras featuring in any film. * Only entered team members can be directly involved in the making of the film. * Films are permitted to use superimposed text.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.247youthfilmfestival.com.au/ Festival website] * [http://www.myspace.com/247youthfilmfestival/ MySpace page moderated by festival officials]
{{DEFAULTSORT:24 7 Film Festival}} [[Category:Film festivals in Australia]] [[Category:Short film festivals]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2002]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Australia]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Year nav|-467}} {{BC year in topic|467}} __NOTOC__ Year '''467 BC''' was a year of the [[Roman calendar|pre-Julian Roman calendar]]. At the time, it was known as the '''Year of the Consulship of Mamercus and Vibulanus''' (or, less frequently, '''year 287 ''[[Ab urbe condita]]'''''). The denomination 467 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the [[Anno Domini]] [[calendar era]] became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.
== Events == <onlyinclude> === By place === ==== Roman Republic ==== * [[Quintus Fabius Vibulanus (467 BC)|Quintus Fabius Vibulanus]] becomes [[List of Republican Roman Consuls|consul of the Roman Republic]] for the first of three times.
==== Sicily ==== * After the death of his brother [[Hiero I]], [[Thrasybulus of Syracuse|Thrasybulus]] becomes [[Tyrant]] of [[Syracuse, Sicily|Syracuse]].
=== By topic === ==== Literature ==== * [[Aeschylus]] writes ''[[Seven Against Thebes]]'' and wins the [[Dionysia]]. * Aeschylus' play, ''[[The Persians]]'' is produced in [[Sicily]].
==== Astronomy ==== * The first recorded sighting of [[Halley's Comet]] occurs.<ref>{{cite journal|quotes= |last = Titchenell|first = Elsa-Brita|date=January 1974|title= Worlds Aborning|journal = [[Sunrise (magazine)|Sunrise]]|url = http://www.theosophy-nw.org/theosnw/science/sc-ebt3.htm |accessdate = 2006-09-22}}</ref> </onlyinclude>
== Births == *
== Deaths == * [[Hiero I]], Tyrant of [[Syracuse, Sicily|Syracuse]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:467 Bc}} [[Category:467 BC| ]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Election | election_name = Algerian legislative election, 2007 | country = Algeria | type = parliamentary | ongoing = no | previous_election = Algerian legislative election, 2002 | previous_year = 2002 | next_election = Algerian legislative election, 2012 | next_year = 2012 | seats_for_election = All 389 seats to the [[People's National Assembly]]
195 seats were needed for a majority | election_date = 17 May 2007 | image1 = [[File:Abdelaziz Belkhadem.jpg|105px]] | leader1 = [[Abdelaziz Belkhadem]] | party1 = National_Liberation_Front_(Algeria) | colour1 = | alliance1 = | leaders_seat1 = | last_election1 = 199 | seats1 = 136 | seat_change1 = {{decrease}}63 | popular_vote1 = 1,315,686 | percentage1 = 22.98% | swing1 = {{decrease}}11.32% | colour2 = | image2 = [[File:Ahmed Ouyahia.jpg|110px]] | leader2 = [[Ahmed Ouyahia]] | alliance2 = | party2 = National_Rally_for_Democracy_(Algeria) | leaders_seat2 = | last_election2 = 47 | seats2 = 61 | seat_change2 = {{increase}}14 | popular_vote2 = 591,310 | percentage2 =10.33% | swing2 = {{increase}}2.13% | title = Prime Minister | before_election = [[Abdelaziz Belkhadem]] | after_election = [[Abdelaziz Belkhadem]] | before_party = National_Liberation_Front_(Algeria) | after_party = National_Liberation_Front_(Algeria) }} {{Politics of Algeria}} '''Legislative elections''' were held in [[Algeria]] on 17 May 2007.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/6653487.stm Q&A: Algerian election] BBC News, 15 May 2007 24 political parties and around 100 independent lists with a total of more than 12,000 candidates competed for the 389 seats in the National People's Assembly. While most Algerians voted on May 17, immigrants from Algeria to other countries (especially [[France]]) and Algerians living in the [[Sahara]] (i.e. Southern Algeria) and other [[nomad]]s and semi-nomads voted on May 16 due to the distance from [[Algiers]], the country's capital. At 35% of the 18.7 million[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/6664165.stm Low turnout in Algeria elections] BBC News, 18 May 2007 voters, the turnout was the lowest in Algerian history.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2007/05/2008525143440191791.html Ruling bloc wins Algeria vote] Al-Jazeera, 18 May 2007[https://mg.co.za/article/2007-05-18-algeria-experiences-lowestever-voter-turnout Algeria experiences lowest-ever voter turnout] Mail & Guardian Online, 18 May 2007 Several political organisations, notably the [[Front of Socialist Forces]],[http://www.ffs-dz.com/article.php?id_article=419 Le FFS a l’honneur, la liberté et le privilège d’annoncer sa décision de non participation au prochain scrutin législatif] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070516023705/http://www.ffs-dz.com/article.php?id_article=419 |date=2007-05-16 }}, FFS, 10 March 2007 the ex-communist [[Democratic and Social Movement (Algeria)|Democratic and Social Movement]],[http://fr.allafrica.com/stories/200705150109.html La Tribune, 15 May 2007] leading members of the former [[Islamic Salvation Front]] ([[Abbassi Madani]][http://www.magharebia.com/cocoon/awi/xhtml1/en_GB/features/awi/features/2007/05/16/feature-01 Algerians play down calls to boycott legislative elections], 16 May 2007 and [[Ali Belhadj]]), the main faction of the split Islamist [[Movement for National Reform|Islah]] Party,[http://www.elislah.net/textspages/bayanet/bayane46.html El Islah release], 14 May 2007 and the newly formed organisation [[Rachad]],[https://web.archive.org/web/20070521052819/http://en.rachad.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=69&Itemid=37 Regarding the “Elections” of 17 May 2007], Rachad, 15 May 2007 had called on their supporters to boycott these elections. These political groups claimed that the elections were consistently rigged by the government, and that participation merely lent a fundamentally corrupt process undeserved legitimacy. The only notable remaining armed group in Algeria, the [[Al-Qaeda Organization in the Islamic Maghreb]], issued a video calling participation in the elections "a great sin", adding its voice to the boycott calls. Tight security measures were implemented to protect the elections; however, two bombs exploded in [[Constantine, Algeria|Constantine]] the day before the election, killing a police officer and wounding five others.[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/E97A0CD9-6872-4279-9AA7-F50C63549D2C.htm Bombings on eve of Algeria election], Al Jazeera English, 16 May 2007. [[Said Bouchair]], the head of the national commission of legislative election control, initially reported that ballot boxes in some areas were being stuffed with FLN ballots, that observers were being prevented from attending, and that some areas refused to open ballot boxes before voting began to allow observers to see whether they were empty or not. He then retracted his statement and apologised.[http://elkhabar.com/FrEn/lire.php?ida=69307&idc=52 Bouchair complains to president then retracted and apologized], El Khabar 19 May 2007, [http://actualite.el-annabi.com/article.php3?id_article=5524 Algérie : Bouchaïr crie à la fraude puis... se rétracte] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927225049/http://actualite.el-annabi.com/article.php3?id_article=5524 |date=2007-09-27 }}, El Annabi 19 May 2007 About 15% of ballots were spoiled. The Constitutional Council confirmed the results of the election, with slight changes to the voter turn-out rate and number of seats won by some parties, on May 21.[http://www.jeuneafrique.com/pays/algerie/article_depeche.asp?art_cle=XIN70027minimlennoi0 "Mini-modification des résultats des législatives par le Conseil constitutionnel"], Xinhua (''[[Jeune Afrique|Jeuneafrique.com]]''), May 22, 2007 {{fr icon}}. It rejected appeals regarding the election on May 30.[http://www.jeuneafrique.com/jeune_afrique/article_depeche.asp?art_cle=AFP03647leconiamuds0 "Le Conseil constitutionnel valide les législatives du 17 mai"], AFP (''[[Jeune Afrique|Jeuneafrique.com]]''), May 30, 2007 {{fr icon}}. ==Results== {{Algerian legislative election, 2007}} Women won 31 seats, which was an increase of eight.[http://www.apn-dz.org/legislature_6/french/liste_femmes_fr.php APN - Listes des depute de la sixieme legislature 2007-2012] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026093946/http://www.apn-dz.org/legislature_6/french/liste_femmes_fr.php |date=2007-10-26 }} Assemblée populaire nationale, 30 May 2007 == References == {{Algerian elections}} [[Category:Elections in Algeria]] [[Category:2007 elections in Africa]] [[Category:2007 in Algeria|Legislative election]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox play | name = André | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | writer = [[William Dunlap]] | chorus = | characters = | mute = | setting = | premiere = {{Start date|1798|03|30}} | place = [[Park Theatre (Manhattan)|Park Theatre]], [[New York City]] | orig_lang = | series = | subject = | genre = | web = }} '''''André; a Tragedy in Five Acts''''' is a play by [[William Dunlap]], first produced at the [[Park Theatre (Manhattan)|Park Theatre]] in New York City on March 30, 1798, by the [[Old American Company]], published in that same year together with a collection of historic documents relating to the case of the title character, [[John André|Major John André]], the British officer who was hanged as a spy on October 2, 1780, for his role in the treason of [[Benedict Arnold]]. The play does not go into the historic details, but rather presents a fictionalized account of the American debate over whether to spare or hang him. Only three characters in the play are historic: André himself, [[George Washington]] (referred to throughout the text, except once in a passage inserted between the first two performances, simply as "The General"), and [[Honora Sneyd]], who had been briefly engaged to André ten years earlier under the auspices of [[Anna Seward]], who had done much to romanticize the affair in her [[Monody on Major André]] of 1781. (Actually, Honora Sneyd had died of consumption some months before André's death, and never went to America.)
Despite the fictionalization, the play genuinely shows the anguish felt by many on the American side over the necessity to hang the brilliant and charming young officer, and it is written in unusually supple verse for the 18th century.
Apart from its intrinsic merits, the play is noteworthy as the first American tragedy written on an American subject. However, despite being nowadays acknowledged as Dunlap's best piece of work, it was, unfortunately, not a great success at the time. Its lack of popularity stemmed from the controversial lionization of André. Moreover, at opening night, the crowd rose to its feet in anger and indignation when Bland, a soldier in the play, hurled his [[cockade]] to the ground at the prospect of André being sentenced to death. The controversy was twofold— not only was Bland losing composure over the fate of a British spy but the cockade (worn by [[Patriot (American Revolution)|Patriots]] and then later by the revolutionaries during the [[French revolution|French Revolution]] to emulate their spirit) being tossed to the floor was interpreted by many as Dunlap attacking the [[American Revolutionary War|American Revolution]] itself.
Dunlap later recycled much of '''''André''''' into his pageant-play ''The Glory of Columbia, Her Yeomanry'', a piece resonating with the [[populism|Populist]] tone in theatre at the time, and which continued to be regularly produced for fifty years.
==External links== * [http://John-W-Kennedy.name/Andre http://John-W-Kennedy.name/Andre] – Full text
{{DEFAULTSORT:Andre (play)}} [[Category:Plays by William Dunlap]] [[Category:1798 plays]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:American Revolutionary War]] [[Category:Plays set in New York (state)]] [[Category:Tragedy plays]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name = Aspen Ideas Festival |image = aspenideasfestivallogo.jpg |size = |caption = |formation = {{start date and age|2005}} |type = [[Academic conference]] |location = [[Aspen, Colorado]], [[United States|U.S.]] |key_people = [[Walter Isaacson]] |website = {{url|http://www.aspenideas.org}} |abbreviation = AIF }} Founded in 2005, the '''Aspen Ideas Festival''' (AIF) is a week-long event held in [[Aspen, Colorado]] in the [[United States]]. The Aspen Ideas Festival program of events includes discussions, [[seminars]], panels, and [[tutorials]] from journalists, designers, innovators, politicians, diplomats, presidents, judges, musicians, artists, and writers.
The Aspen Ideas Festival is a program of the [[Aspen Institute]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.denverpost.com/ci_2840028 |title= Aspen Institute widens its reach |publisher= Denver Post |accessdate= 2013-05-30 |first=Steve |last=Lipsher}}</ref> The AIF format is modeled after educational seminars. Topics covered during the festival include global politics and economics, U.S. Policy, the [[Environmental quality|environment]], [[technology]], [[science]], [[health]], [[education]], the [[arts]], and economic issues.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.aspentimes.com/article/20080701/NEWS/609597788 |title= Aspen Ideas Festival opens |publisher= Aspen Times |accessdate= 2013-05-30}}</ref><ref name="denverpost">{{cite news |url= http://www.denverpost.com/business/ci_4009272 |title= Elite thinkers lured to Aspen |publisher= Denver Post |accessdate= 2013-05-30 |first=Will |last=Shanley}}</ref>
During the festival, live streaming of AIF events is available through the AIF website, ''[[The Atlantic]]'', and [[National Public Radio]].<ref name="NPR">{{cite web |url= https://www.npr.org/about/press/2011/062411.NPRAspenIdeasFestival.html |title= NPR Hosts to Speak at 2011 Aspen Ideas Festival: NPR's 'Talk of the Nation' to Broadcast Live June 28 & 29 from Hotel Jerome |publisher= National Public Radio |accessdate= 2013-06-06}}</ref> Videos and sound clips from past AIF events are archived on the AIF website.<ref name="AIFvideo">{{cite web |url= http://www.aspenideas.org/blog/welcome-aspen-ideas-new-website |title= Aspen Ideas Festival Video Archive |publisher= Aspen Ideas Festival |accessdate= 2013-05-14}}</ref> Presentations and lectures from past Aspen Ideas Festival speakers can also be heard on iTunes U.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://itunes.apple.com/us/itunes-u/aspen-minute/id517052762 |title= Aspen Minute by Aspen Ideas Festival on iTunes U |publisher= Apple |accessdate= 2013-08-20}}</ref>
Past AIF speakers include President [[Bill Clinton]], [[Bill Gates]], [[Ehud Barak]], [[Madeleine Albright]], [[Murray Gell-Mann]], [[Sylvia Earle]], [[Stephen Breyer]], [[Sandra Day O'Connor]], [[Eric Holder]], [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]], [[David Frum]], [[Salam Fayyad]], and [[Paul Ryan]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.politico.com/story/2013/05/aspen-ideas-festival-speakers-91729.html |title= Aspen Ideas Festival roster: A who’s who of politics |publisher= Politico |accessdate= 2013-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.vaildaily.com/article/20090526/AE/905269916 |title= Aspen Ideas Festival announces slate of speakers |publisher= Vail Daily |accessdate= 2013-05-30}}</ref>
== Background ==
=== History ===
The first Aspen Ideas Festival took place in Aspen, Colorado in 2005. The [[Aspen Institute]], under the leadership of [[Walter Isaacson]], developed the Aspen Ideas Festival to gather individuals from various backgrounds and fields of expertise for discussions about global and social issues and innovative ideas.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.aspendailynews.com/section/home/157796 |title= Aspen Ideas Festival Speaker and Program Lineup |publisher= Aspen Daily News |accessdate= 2013-05-14}}</ref> At the first Aspen Ideas Festival in 2005, around 100 speakers attended the festival, among them Jane Goodall, Toni Morrison, Jim Lehrer, Arthur Schlesinger, and many others. The Aspen Ideas Festival modeled its programming for the first festival from some of the Aspen Institute's earliest events, such as the Goethe Bicentennial in 1949.<ref name="denverpost" />
=== The Aspen Institute === {{main article|Aspen Institute}} The Aspen Institute was founded by [[Walter Paepcke]] in 1950 in Aspen, Colorado.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ariane-zurcher/ideas-that-make-a-differe_b_1633117.html |title= Ideas That Make a Difference at the Aspen Ideas Festival |publisher= Huffington Post |accessdate= 2013-05-14 |first=Ariane |last=Zurcher |date=2012-07-03}}</ref> Paepcke was a Chicago businessman and the founder of the Container Corporation of American (CCA). As a Germanophile, he and his wife, Elizabeth Paepcke, actualized a celebration and gathering in Aspen in June 1949 to mark the two-hundredth birthday of [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]]. From the success of the Goethe Bicentennial Festival came the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies. Under Paepcke, the Aspen Institute's programs explored a range of topics through lectures and discussions with top thinkers in a variety of fields from science to the arts.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/The-312/June-2012/Walter-Paepcke-Founder-of-the-Aspen-Institute-and-Chicago-Patron-of-Mid-Century-Modernism/ |title= Walter Paepcke, Founder of the Aspen Institute and Chicago Patron of Mid-Century Modernism |publisher= Chicago Mag |accessdate= 2013-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.lib.uchicago.edu/e/scrc/findingaids/view.php?eadid=ICU.SPCL.PAEPCKEW |title= Guide to the Walter P. Paepcke Papers 1912-1961 |publisher= University of Chicago Library |accessdate= 2013-08-20}}</ref>
Now based in Washington, D.C. with campuses in Aspen and Maryland, the Aspen Institute hosts programs focused on discussion of education and policy issues where presidents, scientists, artists, ambassadors, [[Nobel laureates]], and many others have been in attendance.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.aspeninstitute.org/about/history |title= Aspen Institute History |publisher= Aspen Institute |accessdate= 2013-05-14}}</ref>
== Speakers ==
Since its inception in 2005, Aspen Ideas Festival speakers have included individuals from a wide range of backgrounds, including politicians, diplomats, presidents, judges, scientists, musicians, entrepreneurs, artists, designers and innovators. AIF speakers have participated in discussions and AIF programs for the purpose of sharing their knowledge on subjects related to their expertise, interests, and field of work. These discussions have ranged from the global economy to the environment to theatrical performances and beyond.<ref name="nytimes">{{cite news |url= http://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/07/17/whats-holding-women-back/ |title= What’s Holding Women Back? |publisher= New York Times |accessdate= 2013-05-30 |first=Adriana |last=Gardella |date=2010-07-17}}</ref><ref name="clinton">{{cite news |url= http://www.denverpost.com/newsheadlines/ci_6323470 |title= Clinton urges understanding |publisher= Denver Post |accessdate= 2013-05-30 |first=Troy |last=Hooper}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michael-conniff/creativity-has-designs-on_b_3343894.html |title= Creativity Has Designs On Aspen Ideas Fest |publisher= Huffington Post |accessdate= 2013-06-11 |first=Michael |last=Conniff |date=2013-05-27}}</ref> Past speakers include [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Mitt Romney]], [[Sandra Day O'Conner]], [[Barbra Streisand]], and [[Joe Biden]].
During the 2013 Aspen Ideas Festival, Supreme Court Justice Stephen Breyer discussed recent Supreme Court rulings, including those on the Defense of Marriage Act and the Voting Rights Act, as well as public response following court decisions in the United States and around the world.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.aspendailynews.com/section/home/158536 |title= The harmonious Supreme Court, Lester Crown and the Ideas Fest's big moment |publisher= Aspen Daily News |accessdate= 2013-08-20}}</ref> Renowned Oceanographer, Sylvia Earle, spoke during the 2010 Aspen Ideas Festival about women's issues and education. Earle touched upon the impact of societal pressures on the interest girls and young women take in science and becoming high achievers.<ref name="nytimes" /> Former President Bill Clinton spoke during the 2007 Aspen Ideas Festival, telling the audience about the urgency of accepting globalization and the global world by working interdependently with other cultures and countries for the purpose of achieving cultural understanding and harmonious cross-cultural relationships.<ref name="clinton" />
== Scholars ==
=== Aspen Ideas Festival Scholars ===
The Aspen Ideas Festival Scholars program nominates individuals from all over the world for their unique accomplishments and dedication to improving their communities and making advances in their field of work. Aspen Institute trustees, Aspen Institute senior staff, Aspen Ideas Festival advisors, and past Aspen Ideas Festival scholars select the incoming group of scholars each year. Past Aspen Ideas Festival Scholars include educators, journalists, politicians, writers, and community organizers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aspenideas.org/content/2013-scholars |title=2013 Scholars: 2013 Aspen Ideas Festival Scholars |publisher=Aspen Ideas Festival |accessdate=2013-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130818051137/http://www.aspenideas.org/content/2013-scholars |archivedate=2013-08-18 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/28/pitch-competition-aspen-ideas-festival_n_3517751.html |title= The First Pitch Competition Hits The Aspen Ideas Festival |publisher= Huffington Post |accessdate= 2013-08-20}}</ref>
=== Bezos Scholars ===
Part of the Aspen Ideas Festival since 2005, the Bezos Scholars program invites twelve public high school students in the eleventh grade and twelve educators to attend the Aspen Ideas Festival. The Bezos Scholars attend Aspen Ideas Festival programs and events, as well as discussions and engagements designed only for Bezos Scholars. After attending the Aspen Ideas Festival, the Scholars return to their hometowns in order to produce a localized version of the Aspen Ideas Festival, a Local Ideas Festivals, inspired by their experiences in Aspen.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bezosfamilyfoundation.org/scholars |title= Bezos Scholars Program @ The Aspen Institute |publisher= Bezos Family Foundation |accessdate= 2013-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jeffrey-abelson/bezos-scholars-program-in_b_846705.html |title= Bezos Scholars Program -- Incubating Big Ideas and Model Citizens -- One High School at a Time |publisher= Huffington Post |accessdate= 2013-08-20 |first=Jeffrey |last=Abelson |date=2011-04-11}}</ref>
== Impacts ==
In 2012, [[Stanley McChrystal]] was interviewed by [[Bob Schieffer]] at the festival. As part of that interview, McChrystal was asked whether or not he believed in the draft. He responded that he thought every young person should serve, but the military doesn’t need every young person, so we need to create more opportunities for all young Americans to serve.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stanley McChrystal on Leadership|url=https://www.aspenideas.org/session/stanley-mcchrystal-leadership|website=Aspen Ideas Festival|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> The [[Franklin Project]] -- an initiative to make a year of national service a common opportunity and expectation for young Americans -- was created as a result of this festival conversation. [[Walter Isaacson]] called the Franklin Project the “biggest idea” to come out of the festival during his tenure as CEO of the [[Aspen Institute]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Carroll|first1=Rick|title=Q&A with Walter Isaacson of the Aspen Institute|url=https://www.aspentimes.com/news/qa-with-walter-isaacson-of-the-aspen-institute/|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=The Aspen Times|date=25 June 2017}}</ref>
== References ==
{{reflist}}
== External links == * {{URL | http://www.aspenideas.org | Aspen Ideas Festival Official Website}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox military conflict | partof = | image = Democratic Republic of the Congo (26 provinces) - Tanganyika.svg | caption = {{nowrap|Location of Tanganyika Province in the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} | date = 2013–present
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|month1=12|day1=31|year1=2013}}) | place = [[Tanganyika Province|Tanganyika]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] | status = Ongoing | territory = | combatant1 = Pygmy Batwa militias * "Perci"{{cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/08/11/dr-congo-ethnic-militias-attack-civilians-katanga |title=DR Congo: Ethnic Militias Attack Civilians in Katanga |last1= |first1= |work=[[Human Rights Watch]] |date=11 August 2015 |accessdate=25 September 2017}} | combatant2 = Luba militias * "Elements" | commander1 = | commander2 = | strength1 = | strength2 = | units1 = | units2 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = Hundreds killed,{{cite news|title=DR Congo: Ethnic Militias Attack Civilians in Katanga|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/08/11/dr-congo-ethnic-militias-attack-civilians-katanga|accessdate=10 April 2017|publisher=Human Rights Watch|date=11 August 2015}} 650,000 displaced{{cite web|url=https://www.icrc.org/en/document/democratic-republic-congo-communal-violence-malnutrition-tanganyika |title=Stricken by communal violence and malnutrition in Tanganyika, Democratic Republic of the Congo |publisher=[[International Committee of the Red Cross]] |date=29 December 2017 |accessdate=19 March 2018}} | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Conflict in Congo}} }} The '''Batwa–Luba clashes''' are a series of ongoing clashes in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] (DRC) the [[Pygmy]] [[Twa#Congo|Batwa people]],{{efn|name=fn1|The two major divisions of Pygmies in the DRC are the Bambuti, or [[Mbuti people|Mbuti]], who largely live in the [[Ituri forest]] in the northeast, and the [[Twa#Congo|Batwa]], but many Batwa in certain areas of the country also refer to themselves as Bambuti.{{cite web|url=http://minorityrights.org/minorities/batwa-and-bambuti/|title=Democratic Republic of the Congo - Batwa and Bambuti|publisher=Minority Rights Group International}}}} and the [[Luba people]] starting in 2013. ==Background== The pygmy Batwa are often exploited and allegedly [[Pygmy peoples#slavery|enslaved]] by the Luba and other Bantu groups. While the pygmy never organized militarily to resist, starting with the [[First Congo War]], rebel leader [[Laurent-Désiré Kabila]], who won the war, organized the Twa into paramilitary groups to help him. His son, [[Joseph Kabila]], who succeeded him, used these militias in the [[Second Congo War]] and against the predominately Luba [[Mai-Mai Kata Katanga]]. ==Course of the conflict== [[File:IDPs near Kalemie (2017).jpg|thumb|left|[[Internally displaced person|IDPs]] from [[Nyunzu Territory]] who have fled the clashes between [[Twa#Congo|Batwa]] and [[Luba people|Luba]].]] In [[Tanganyika Province]], in the northern part of the former [[Katanga Province]], starting in 2013, Pygmy Batwa rose up into militias, such as the "Perci" militia, and attacked Luba villages.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/01/world/africa/in-congo-wars-are-small-and-chaos-is-endless.html?_r=0|title=In Congo, Wars Are Small and Chaos Is Endless|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=7 March 2017|date=30 April 2016}} A Luba militia known as "Elements" attacked back, notably killing at least 30 people in the "Vumilia 1" displaced people camp in April 2015. Since the start of the conflict, hundreds have been killed and tens of thousands have been displaced from their homes. The weapons used in the conflict are often arrows, axes, and [[machete]]s, rather than guns.{{cite news|url=https://www.heise.de/tp/features/Kongo-Pygmaeen-gegen-Bantu-3820135.html |title=Kongo: Pygmäen gegen Bantu |last1=Mühlbauer |first1=Peter |work=[[Heinz Heise]] |language=German |date=1 September 2017|accessdate=25 September 2017}} In October 2015, Pygmy and Luba leaders sign a peace deal to end the conflict.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-congodemocratic-conflict/pygmy-and-bantu-leaders-sign-peace-deal-in-southeast-congo-idUSKCN0SF1YY20151021|title=Pygmy and Bantu leaders sign peace deal in southeast Congo|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=30 December 2017|date=21 October 2015}} In September 2016, the United Nations along with provincial authorities established local councils called "baraza" to address grievances and this appeared to reduce the violence.{{cite news|url=http://www.irinnews.org/feature/2017/07/11/displaced-congolese-civilians-sent-back-widening-war|title=Displaced Congolese civilians sent back to a widening war|publisher=irinnews.com|accessdate=18 July 2017|date=11 July 2017}} However, clashes intensified at the end of 2016,{{cite web|url=http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20DR%20Congo%20Humanitarian%20Sitrep%2C%20November-December%202016.pdf|title=Democratic Republic of the Congo Humanitarian Situation Report|publisher=Reliefweb}} as the government tried to enforce a tax on caterpillars that the Batwa harvest as important food source,{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37695489 |title='Caterpillar tax': DR Congo ethnic clash sees 16 killed |last1= |first1= |work=[[BBC]] |date=18 October 2016 |accessdate=25 September 2017}} while the military attempted to arrest a Twa warlord. Both of these events led to a violent backlash and a spread of the fighting. Twa militias also started to target Tutsis, another Bantu group, by slaughtering their cows. A ceasefire brokered by the [[United Nations]] in February 2017 failed, and the violence continued.{{cite news|url=http://www.taz.de/!5441270/ |title=Vertrieben und schutzlos |last1=Johnson |first1=Dominic |work=[[Die Tageszeitung]] |language=German |date=1 September 2017|accessdate=25 September 2017}} In August 2017, the clashes intensified after Batwa attacked a group of Luba near [[Kalemie]]; in course of the following fighting about 50 people died, most of them Luba.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-congo-security/dozens-killed-in-ethnic-violence-in-eastern-congo-idUSKBN1AM0HM |title=Dozens killed in ethnic violence in eastern Congo |author= |work=[[Reuters]] |date=6 August 2017 |accessdate=5 October 2017}} Batwa fighters also attacked a [[MONUSCO]] convoy with arrows. A number of [[United Nations peacekeeping|Blue Helmets]] were wounded, though they still opted not to return fire. By the end of 2017, 650,000 people had been displaced due to the fighting. The economy in Tanganyika had mostly collapsed, while fields could no longer be harvested.{{cite web|url=https://www.icrc.org/en/document/democratic-republic-congo-tanganyika-eat-snails-conflict-violence-hunger |title=Tanganyika: At a snail’s pace |author= |work=[[International Committee of the Red Cross]] |date=14 March 2018 |accessdate=19 March 2018}} As result, malnutrition spread amongst those who had fled, as well as those who stayed at their homes. ==Casualties== ===Deaths=== More than a thousand people were killed in the first eight months of 2014 alone. ===Displaced people=== The number of displaced people are estimated to be 650,000 as of December 2017. Around March 2017, 543,000 had fled, up from 370,000 in December 2016, the strongest growth of the current conflicts in the Congo, which has the largest population of displaced people in Africa. Many refugees are allegedly forced by the government to leave the camps and return to their homes, where the fighting still continues. == Notes == {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *Reliefweb, [http://reliefweb.int/report/democratic-republic-congo/drc-humanitarian-situation-report-24-november-2016], November 24, 2016 {{Years in the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} {{Ongoing military conflicts}} {{Post-Cold War African conflicts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Batwa-Luba clashes}} [[Category:2013 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:2014 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:2015 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:2016 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:2017 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Ongoing insurgencies]] [[Category:Civil wars involving the states and peoples of Africa]] [[Category:Wars involving the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Military history of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2016]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2017]] [[Category:Ongoing conflicts]] [[Category:Insurgencies in Africa]]

revision.text:
[[File:BuxtonOperaHouse.jpg|right|300px|Buxton Opera House|thumb]] [[Image:Buxton Opera House Sign.jpg|thumb|300px|Detail above the entrance]] [[File:BuxtonOHuppertiers.jpg|thumb|300px|Upper tiers in the house]]
'''Buxton Opera House''' is in The Square, [[Buxton]], [[Derbyshire]], England. It is a 902-seat opera house that hosts the annual [[Buxton Festival]] and, from 1994 to 2013, the [[International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival]], among others, as well as [[pantomime]] at Christmas, [[musical theatre|musicals]] and other entertainments year-round. Hosting live performances until 1927, the theatre then was used mostly as a cinema until 1976. In 1979, it was refurbished and reopened as a venue for live performance.
==History== It was built in 1903 and designed by [[Frank Matcham]], one of Britain's finest theatre architects. He also designed a number of famous [[London]] theatres, including the [[London Palladium]] (1910) and the [[Coliseum Theatre|London Coliseum]] (1904).
The Opera House ran as a successful theatre, receiving touring companies until 1927, when it was turned into a cinema. Silent films were shown until 1932 when the theatre was wired for sound and could present ‘talkies’. The Opera House also became the venue for an annual summer theatre festival from 1936 to 1942, two of them in conjunction with [[Lillian Bayliss]] and her London-based [[Old Vic]] company. After the Second World War, the theatre continued to serve primarily as a cinema, although the Literary and Dramatic Societies of local schools [[Buxton College]] and Cavendish Grammar School staged annual performances of either [[Shakespeare]], such as ''[[Hamlet]]'' (1966), ''[[Coriolanus]]'' (1968) and ''[[Macbeth]]'' (1970), or modern works, such as [[Bertold Brecht]]'s ''[[Life of Galileo]]'' (1967) and [[Dylan Thomas]]'s ''The Doctor & the Devils'' (1969).<ref>Bolton King, R 1973 Buxton College, 1675–1970</ref>
In 2014, the opera house's former finance chief was jailed for two years for stealing nearly £250,000 from the opera house accounts in 2012 and 2013.<ref>[http://www.buxtonadvertiser.co.uk/news/local/ex-finance-chief-jailed-for-250-000-buxton-opera-house-fraud-1-6712061 "Ex-finance chief jailed for £250,000 Buxton Opera House fraud"], ''Buxton Advertiser'', 4 July 2014.</ref>
==Refurbishment and reception== [[File:Buxtonstageandpit.jpg|thumb|left|Stage, boxes and orchestra pit]] The Opera House gradually fell into disrepair. In 1976, it was closed and rumours circulated that it would never reopen. In 1979, however, it was restored and an [[orchestra pit]] was added to the original Frank Matcham design. Since then, the Opera House has been a full-time venue for stage productions, presenting approximately 450 performances per year, including opera, dance, [[musical theatre]], [[pantomime]], comedy, drama, children's shows and concerts. The theatre is staffed by a small full-time technical crew for all the backstage work, setting up all the shows and artists that appear. Volunteers from the local community are also employed for front-of-house duties including bar work and as ushers.
By the 1990s, more work was needed to repair and modernise the theatre, and from 1999 to 2001 an extensive programme of internal and external restoration took place. In February 2007, another refurbishment was completed at the Opera House that saw the installation of air conditioning in the gallery and backstage area, new seats in the gallery and upper circle, a new get-in lift to replace the ramp and new backstage working lights as well as re-wiring and painting the backstage area and dressing rooms. The current capacity is 902 seats.<ref name=PAC/>
In 2011, ''[[FT Magazine]]'' featured an article on opera house design. In the section called "My favourite experiences", the writer praised the European opera houses "designed by the Viennese architectural firm of Fellner and Helmer (the [[Zurich Opera House]] is [an] example) ... [which] represent a near-ideal marriage of size, acoustic and decorative beauty. Their British equivalents are those designed by [[Frank Matcham]] – best of all the Buxton Opera House."<ref>Clark, Andrew. [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/793470dc-faa5-11e0-8fe7-00144feab49a.html#axzz1bf0DIXqA "Something completely magical: My favourite opera experiences",] ''FT Magazine'', 21 October 2011</ref>
==Theatre complex== The theatre complex also includes the adjacent Pavilion Gardens, the 369-seat Pavilion Arts Centre (rebuilt in 2010; formerly the Paxton Theatre),<ref name=PAC>Woolman, Natalie. [http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/29520/buxton-opera-house-to-open-new-pavilion-arts "Buxton Opera House to open new Pavilion arts venue"]. ''The Stage'', 7 September 2010</ref> and the Octagon Hall auditorium (built in 1875), as well as a two-storey restaurant with a bar and gift shop. The arts centre stage area can be converted into a separate 93-seat studio theatre.<ref>[http://derbyshire.greatbritishlife.co.uk/article/the-opening-of-the-pavilion-art-centre-buxton-derbyshire-24528/ "The opening of the Pavilion art centre Buxton"]. ''Derbyshire Life'', 26 August 2010</ref>
==Festivals== Since July 1979, the Opera House and theatre complex has been home to the [[Buxton Festival]], which runs for about two weeks in mid-July and has developed into one of Britain's largest opera-based festivals. Typically, it includes a [[George Frideric Handel|Handel]] opera (with conductors such as Harry Christophers) and other rarely seen operas as well as more popular classics. Running alongside it is the [[Buxton Festival Fringe]]. It is popular as a warm-up for the [[Edinburgh Fringe]], and it now claims to be the largest 'true' fringe festival in the UK. From 1994 to 2013, the Opera House also hosted the annual three-week-long [[International Gilbert and Sullivan Festival]], attracting audiences from all over the UK and from abroad.<ref>Christiansen, Rupert. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/opera/10176800/Gilbert-and-Sullivan-Festival-bows-out-of-Buxton.html "Gilbert and Sullivan Festival bows out of Buxton"], ''The Telegraph'', 15 July 2013</ref>
The Opera House presents over 400 performances each year.<ref>[http://www.laughingaudience.co.uk/buxton-opera-house.html "Buxton Opera House"]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Paul Iles & The Laughing Audience, accessed 18 February 2011</ref> Since 2004, the Opera House and the neighbouring Pavilion Gardens have hosted the annual Four Four Time music festival which sees a wide variety of musical performances over one week in February. Performers for the 2008 festival included [[Marc Almond]], [[Richard Hawley]], [[The Stranglers]] and [[Boy George]].
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.buxtonoperahouse.org.uk/ Buxton Opera House official website]
{{Derbyshire Places of interest}} {{coord|53.2586|-1.9157|type:city_region:GB|display=title}}
[[Category:Buxton|Opera House]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Derbyshire]] [[Category:Tourist attractions of the Peak District]] [[Category:Theatres in Derbyshire]] [[Category:Opera houses in England]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1903]] [[Category:Music venues completed in 1903]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event | |name=Canadian Tulip Festival |logo= |image=May 2006.jpg |caption=[[Tulip]]s from the 2006 Tulip Festival. |location=[[National Capital Region (Canada)]] |years_active=1953–present |dates=2 weeks leading through Victoria Day |genre=[[Horticultural]] [[Arts & Culture]] |website=[http://www.tulipfestival.ca www.tulipfestival.ca] }} The '''Canadian Tulip Festival''' ({{lang-fr|Festival Canadien des Tulipes}}; {{lang-nl|Canadees Festival van de Tulp}}) is a [[tulip festival]], held annually in May in [[Ottawa|Ottawa, Ontario]], Canada. The festival claims to be the world's largest tulip festival, displaying over one million [[tulip]]s,<ref>{{cite web |format=PDF |url=http://festivaldestulipes.ca/TulipTimeWeb2010.pdf |title=Tulip Times |page=4 |accessdate=October 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601213845/http://festivaldestulipes.ca/TulipTimeWeb2010.pdf |archivedate=June 1, 2010 |df= }}</ref> with attendance of over 650,000 visitors annually.<ref>{{cite press release | title =Showcasing Canada's Capital Region | publisher =Canadian Tulip Festival | year =2007 | url =http://www.tulipfestival.ca/en/News/index.php | accessdate =2007-05-18 }}</ref> Large displays of tulips are planted throughout the city, and the largest display of tulips is found in [[Commissioners Park (Ottawa)|Commissioners Park]] on the shores of [[Dow's Lake]], and along the [[Rideau Canal]] with 300,000 tulips planted there alone.<ref>NCC</ref> Millions of tulips set the stage for a celebration of authentic art, cultural, historic, culinary and family tulip experiences at various official venues across the capital.
== History == In 1945, the [[Dutch royal family]] sent 100,000 [[tulip]] bulbs to [[Ottawa]] in gratitude for Canadians having sheltered the future [[Queen Juliana]] and her family for the preceding three years during the [[Nazi occupation of the Netherlands]] in the [[Second World War]]. The most noteworthy event during their time in Canada was the birth in 1943 of [[Princess Margriet]] at the [[The Ottawa Hospital|Ottawa Civic Hospital]]. The maternity ward was temporarily declared to be extraterritorial by the Canadian government, thereby allowing Princess Margriet's citizenship to be solely influenced by her mother's Dutch citizenship.<ref>{{cite web|title = Proclamation|url = http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/databases/canada-gazette/093/001060-119.01-e.php?document_id_nbr=9450&f=g|publisher = ''[[Canada Gazette]]''|date = 26 December 1942|accessdate = 18 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=1943: Netherlands’ Princess Margriet born in Ottawa - CBC Archives|url=http://www.cbc.ca/archives/entry/1943-netherlands-princess-margriet-born-in-ottawa|website=CBC Archives|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=23 January 1992|accessdate=18 June 2017|language=en}}</ref> In 1946, Juliana sent another 20,500 bulbs requesting that a display be created for the hospital, and promised to send 10,000 more bulbs each year.
=== The festival begins === [[File:Her Royal Highness Princess Margriet of the Netherlands in Ottawa.jpg|thumb|Princess Margriet returns to Ottawa to attend the Canadian Tulip Festival in May 2002.]] In the years following Queen Juliana's original donation, Ottawa became famous for its tulips and in 1953 the [[Ottawa Board of Trade]] and photographer [[Malak Karsh]] organized the first "Canadian Tulip Festival". Queen Juliana returned to celebrate the festival in 1967, and Princess Margriet returned in 2002 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the festival.
=== Outdoor music concerts === For many years, the festival featured a series of outdoor [[music]] concerts in addition to the tulips. The 1972 festival saw [[Liberace]] give an opening concert, and at the 1987 festival, Canadian singer [[Alanis Morissette]] made her first appearance at the age of 12.<ref>[http://www.tulipfestival.ca/en/Education/E-History_of_CTF.pdf ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060301021413/http://www.tulipfestival.ca/en/Education/E-History_of_CTF.pdf |date=March 1, 2006 }}</ref> [[The Trews]] first became widely known after opening for [[Big Sugar]] at the 2003 festival. Montreal's [[General Rudie]] also gained valuable exposure early in their career with a performance at the 2000 festival.
After several years of cold and rainy weekends drove the festival to the brink of bankruptcy in 2006, the outdoor music concerts were discontinued. Even though concert admission fees were a source of revenue for the festival, rainy weather contributed to low concert attendance on many occasions, making the concerts a heavy financial risk.
=== 2007: Reorganisation === In 2007, the festival was reorganised under new leadership. The festival was redesigned to focus on promoting international friendship, the original symbolic role of the gift of tulips. Park admission charges were eliminated and a new feature called ''Celebr'''idée''': a Celebration of Ideas'' was introduced. Another component of the 2007 festival was a fund-raising effort in support of [[War Child (charity)|War Child]] Canada.
=== Celebridée === Beyond celebrating the tulip as a symbol of beauty and friendship, the Canadian Tulip Festival, through Celebridée, aims to present some of the most brilliant thinkers of our time speaking about ideas that matter.
Celebridée has continued to grow since its inception in 2007. 2008's speakers included such diverse and thought-provoking individuals as Sir [[Salman Rushdie]], Wired Magazine's [[Chris Anderson (writer)|Chris Anderson]], Pulitzer Prize-winning author of ''[[Guns, Germs and Steel]]'' [[Jared Diamond]], and world-renowned pianist [[Angela Hewitt]].
==Festival sites and themes== {| class="infobox bordered" style="text-align:left" cellpadding=4 |+ style="line-height:150%"|'''Recent Canadian Tulip Festival Themes''' |- |1994 | A Tribute to the Origin Country of the Tulip - Turkey |- |1995 | The Friendship That Flowered 50th anniversary of the Liberation of the Netherlands |- |1996 | Floral Tribute to Nice |- |1997 | Floral Artistry of Japan |- |1998 | A Celebration of Canada's Provinces and Territories |- |1999 | Between Friends |- |2000 | Tulips 2000: A Capital Celebration! |- |2001 | Tulips Forever! A Salute to Britain |- |2002 | Tulipmania! 50th Anniversary |- |2003 | G'day Australia – Tulips Down Under |- |2004 | Canada's Tulip Experience |- |2005 | A Celebration of Peace and Friendship |- |2006 | Tulips 2006 – World Flower Rendezvous! |- |2007 | "Celebr'''IDÉE''' A Celebration of Ideas" inaugural year |- |2008 | Where Ideas Bloom |- |2009 | The Tulip Route |- |2010 | "Liberation" - The 65th anniversary of the liberation of Europe. |- |2011 | "Kaleidoscope" - A celebration of Spring awakening through colour, culture and community |- |2012 | "60th anniversary" |- |2013 | |- |2014 | |- |2015 | |- |2016 | |- |2017 | One Tulip One Canada |- |2018 | A World of Tulips |}
'''Official Sites''' *Lansdowne Park – The Art & Culture Tulip Experience *Commissioners Park – Dow's Lake - The Garden Tulip Experience; *ByWard Market – The Urban Tulip Experience; *Garden Promenade – The Community Tulip Experience *Zibi Gatineau - The Culinary Tulip Experience
'''Attraction Sites''' *[[Canadian Museum of Nature]] *[[National Gallery of Canada]] *[[Royal Canadian Mint]] *[[Library and Archives Canada]] *[[Canadian War Museum]] *[[Canadian Museum of Civilization]]
'''Partner Sites''' *[[Rideau Hall]] *Mackenzie King Estate ([[Gatineau Park]]){{Clear}}
==Trivia== Because of the ongoing Canadian support for the Netherlands during the war, Seymour Cobley of the [[Royal Horticultural Society]] actually donated 83,000 tulips to Canada from 1941–1943, several years before the Royal Family followed suit.<ref name="godutch">{{cite news|url=http://www.godutch.com/windmill/newsItem.asp?id=166 |title=Crown princess Juliana in 1945 said thanks with loads of tulips |work=The Windmill news articles |publisher=goDutch |date=1943-01-19 |accessdate=2012-05-24}}</ref>
Photographer [[Malak Karsh]] became widely known for his photographs of the Tulip Festival.
While the Netherlands continues to send 20,000 bulbs to Canada each year (10,000 from the Royal Family and 10,000 from the Dutch Bulb Growers Association), by 1963 the festival featured more than 2 million, and today sees nearly 3 million tulips purchased from Dutch and Canadian distributors.<ref name="godutch"/>
==Official Festival Sites==
===Commissioner's Park - Dow's Lake === {{main|Commissioners Park (Ottawa)}} [[File:Ottawa Tulip Festival.jpeg|thumb|Tulips at Dows Lake in 2014]] Commissioner's Park, on the shores of Dow's Lake is a major centre of activity for the Tulip Festival. The largest concentration of tulips in the [[National Capital Region (Canada)|National Capital Region]] — some 300,000 — can be found planted along a 1 km section of the lakeshore. Commissioners Park also features buskers and musicians, and artists demonstrating their skills.{{Clear}}
===Garden Promenade - The Community Tulip Experience=== The Garden Promenade celebrates Ottawa's garden culture with over 70 experiences through 40 of the region's most beautiful must-visit gardens. Join us during the Canadian Tulip Festival and delight in a self-guided or escorted showcase of Ottawa's public gardens exploding with millions of tulips in bloom and many tulip centric special activities planned such as Yoga in the Tulips on Parliament Hill and in Major's Hill Park. www.gardenpromenade.ca
=== Other Garden Promenade sites === [[Image:Garden of the Provinces and Territories - Tulip Festival - 4.jpg|thumb|left|2005 Garden of the Provinces & Territories]]The [[Garden of the Provinces and Territories]], located directly across from [[Library and Archives Canada]] on [[Wellington Street (Ottawa)|Wellington Street]] is one of many sites that the [[National Capital Commission]] plants with thousands of tulips. Others include [[Parliament Hill]], the banks of the [[Rideau Canal]], and in Gatineau, [[Jacques Cartier Park]], [[Montcalm-Taché Park]], and the Malak flowerbed behind the Canadian Museum of Civilization.{{Clear}}{{Clear}} [[File:Aberdeen Pavilion. Ottawa, Ontario.jpg|thumb|Aberdeen Pavilion]]
'''<big>Lansdowne Park Tulip Gallery – The Art & Culture Tulip Experience</big>'''
Aberdeen Pavilion and the Great Lawn will be brimming with tulip art and floral exhibits, artistic installations, interactive family programming and entertainment. Varying international exhibits have been featured during many years of the festival's history. International representation is limited to official members of the festivals tulip friendship network comprising like-minded nations who celebrate and revere the tulip as an international symbol of friendship and peace. Many of these countries stage large-scale tulip festivals of their own.
Special features at Lansdowne Park include: * Thousands of potted tulips and floral installations * International pavilions offering food, artworks and entertainment sponsored by friendship country embassies * Spectacular garden of 5-foot hand painted tulips * Art, Floral and gardening demos, seminars and workshops * Children's Tulip Garden Installation (thousands of wooden tulips hand painted by local elementary school children) * Vintage Ford Model A Autombile Display and Picnic * Interactive Family Fun Zone and Pavilion * Friendship Stage * Homage To Malak Photography Exhibit * Signatures Canadian Handmade Market * Tulip Bouquet Exhibit * Tulip Art Gallery & Boutique * Victory Encampment- Vintage Military Displays '''ByWard Market: The Urban Tulip Experience'''
Each year, the Canadian artists invited to create the annual festival campaign imagery brings tulip art to this city's central marketplace with massive urban art installations, interactive workshops and artist meet & greet opportunities. Animation throughout the streets and tulip-centric merchant promotions compliment the experience.
==See also== {{portal|Ottawa}} * [[Liberation Day (The Netherlands)]] * [[Canada-Netherlands relations]] * [[National Tulip Day]] in The Netherlands *[[National Canadian Liberation Monument]], with its own "Man with Two Hats" sculpture
==References== <references/>
==External links== *{{official|http://www.tulipfestival.ca}} *[https://ninanearandfar.com/2017/05/24/the-story-of-ottawa-tulip-festival/ "The Story of the Ottawa Tulip Festival"]
{{Ottawa landmarks}}
[[Category:Festivals in Ottawa]] [[Category:Flower festivals]] [[Category:Gardening in Canada]] [[Category:1953 establishments in Ontario]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1953]] [[Category:Annual events in Canada]] [[Category:Flower festivals in Canada]] [[Category:Spring (season) events in Canada]]

revision.text:
{{for|other peasant revolts|List of peasant revolts}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict = Carinthian Peasant Revolt |partof= |campaign = |colour_scheme = background:#bbcccc | image = Coccau Field 01.JPG | image_size = 300 |caption = View over the Kokovo Field |casus = |date = 1478 |place = [[Duchy of Carinthia]] (modern [[Austria]]) |result = Suppression of revolt and execution of participants |territory = |combatant1 = Peasant Army |combatant2 = |commander1 = Peter Wunderlich{{KIA}} |commander2 = |strength1 = 3,000 |strength2 = |casualties1 = 300 |casualties2 = }} The '''Carinthian Peasant Revolt''' ({{lang-de|Kärntner Bauernaufstand}}; {{lang-sl|koroški kmečki upor}}) took place in the [[Duchy of Carinthia]] (present-day [[Austria]]) in 1478. It was the first of several larger [[peasant revolt]]s in the area of [[Inner Austria]]. After several [[Ottoman Wars in Europe|Ottoman]] raids from 1473 onwards, the rural population established a peasants' association that was an effort to take the defence of the farmers' homes into their own hands and was also aimed against the ruling nobility that had failed to protect the farmers from attacks by marauding Turkish [[akinji]] cavalry. The revolt was eventually suppressed.<ref name="Cvirn2000">{{cite book |title=Ilustrirana zgodovina Slovencev |language=Slovenian |trans-title=The Illustrated History of the Slovenes |chapter=Kmečki upor na slovenskem Koroškem |trans-chapter=The Peasant Revolt in Slovene Carinthia |year=2000 |first=Peter |last=Štih |editor-first=Marko |editor-last=Vidic |publisher=Mladinska knjiga |isbn=86-11-15664-1 |page=132}}</ref>
==Background== {{Unreferenced section|date=February 2013}} The [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] forces had entered the [[Balkan]] peninsula during the disintegration of the [[Serbian Empire]] in the 14th century. In 1389 they defeated a Serbian army at the [[Battle of Kosovo]]. Upon the [[Fall of Constantinople]] in 1453, Turkish troops advanced northwestwards and in 1469 reached the borders of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] entering the southeastern [[Duchy of Carniola]].
In view of the threat, the Carinthian estates had strong fortifications erected and mountain pass routes secured. The [[House of Habsburg|Habsburg]] administration under Emperor [[Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick III]] imposed new taxes and contributions on the local population to fund the operations. Nevertheless, in late September 1473, Ottoman forces first crossed the [[Seeberg Saddle]] and plundered the [[Drava]] and [[Glan (Gurk)|Glan]] valleys. Again in 1476, they moved into Carinthia from the upper [[Sava]] valley, laid siege to the [[Arnoldstein]] monastery, moved into the [[Gail (river)|Gail]] valley and devastated the area of [[Villach]]. They set up a camp at [[Wernberg]], from where they started further raids.
==Course== Carinthia saw five Turkish incursions into its territory between 1473 and 1483, with lots of plundering and killing at the hands of Turkish cavalry. According to the contemporary chronicler Jakob Unrest, the local nobility had no answer to the large numbers of Turkish cavalry, they moved into their fortified castles, while the clergy fortified its churches and monasteries and held out there. This left the peasants of Carinthia without any protection. Modelled on the [[Old Swiss Confederacy|Swiss Confederacy]], they decided to take their faith into their own hands.
On 2 February 1478, the Carinthian Peasants' League (German: ''Kärntner Bauernbund'') was formed in the [[Counts of Ortenburg|Ortenburg]] lands at [[Spittal an der Drau]] under the leadership of one Peter Wunderlich, raising some concern among the local nobility and clergy. Meanwhile, the [[Ottoman–Venetian War (1463–79)|Ottoman–Venetian War]] raged through the [[Soča|Isonzo]] valley in the south, where the Turks unsuccessfully besieged the fortress of [[Gradisca]] and then turned northwards into the [[Julian Alps]]. In May the farmers gathered at Villach where they organized a 3,000-strong army to face the invaders. They started obstructing the steep [[Predil Pass]] route, however, a 20,000-strong Turkish contingent of professional akinji cavalry were able to remove the barriers and to abseil their horses over rocky terrain.
When on June 25 the Ottoman forces came down the mountains and neared [[Tarvisio|Tarvis]], most peasants fled overnight to protect their belongings. The next day only a small group of some 530 peasants and 70 miners from [[Bad Bleiberg|Bleiberg]] chose to make a stand against the Turks and to try to stop them at the [[Battle of Kokovo]] (Goggau) near Tarvis. About 300 men died in the futile attempt, surrounded and slain by about 20,000 akinji horsemen. The Turkish army broke through and proceeded to plunder all the way up to [[Millstatt Abbey]] and [[Gmünd, Carinthia|Gmünd]] in Upper Carinthia.
==Epilogue== Immediately after the withdrawal of the Ottoman forces, the rest of the revolting peasants were accused of treachery and eventually put on trial for their revolt. The leader of the uprising Peter Wunderlich was captured near Gmünd, sentenced to death and publicly [[dismembered]] in [[Lendorf]]. The peasants remained hard-pressed, particularly as Emperor Frederick moreover entered into the [[Austrian–Hungarian War (1477–88)|Austrian–Hungarian War]] against King [[Matthias Corvinus]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== *[[Slovene Peasant Revolt]] *[[List of peasant revolts]]
{{Medieval and Early Modern European Peasant Wars}}
[[Category:Conflicts in 1478]] [[Category:Popular revolt in late-medieval Europe]] [[Category:Peasant revolts]] [[Category:1478 in Europe]] [[Category:15th-century rebellions]] [[Category:Duchy of Carinthia]] [[Category:Rebellions in Austria]] [[Category:Slovene rebellions]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/50.200.227.134|50.200.227.134]] ([[User talk:50.200.227.134|talk]]) to last revision by Flooded with them hundreds. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{For|the idea that Earth-like planets have been affected in the past by short-lived, violent galaxy-wide events|Neocatastrophism}} [[Image:Mount St. Helens, one day before the devastating eruption.jpg|thumb|right|250px|alt=Conical mountain|[[Mount St. Helens]], 9:00 am, May 17, 1980.]] [[File:MSH80 eruption mount st helens 05-18-80.jpg|thumb|right|170px|Eruption column around 8:35 am on May 18, 1980.]]
'''Catastrophism''' was the theory that the [[Earth]] had largely been shaped by sudden, short-lived, violent events, possibly worldwide in scope.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Turney |first=C.S.M. |last2=Brown |first2=H. |year=2007 |title=Catastrophic early Holocene sea level rise, human migration and the Neolithic transition in Europe |journal=[[Quaternary Science Reviews]] |volume=26 |pages=2036–2041 |bibcode= 2007QSRv...26.2036T |doi=10.1016/j.quascirev.2007.07.003 |issue=17–18}}</ref> This was in contrast to [[uniformitarianism (science)|uniformitarianism]] (sometimes described as [[gradualism]]), in which slow incremental changes, such as [[erosion]], created all the Earth's [[geology|geological]] features. Uniformitarianism held that the present was the key to the past, and that all geological processes (such as [[erosion]]) throughout the past were like those that can be observed now. Since the early disputes, a more inclusive and integrated view of geologic events has developed, in which the [[scientific consensus]] accepts that there were some catastrophic events in the geologic past, but these were explicable as extreme examples of natural processes which can occur.
Catastrophism held that [[geological epoch]]s had ended with violent and sudden natural catastrophes such as great floods and the rapid [[orogeny|formation of major mountain chains]]. Plants and animals living in the parts of the world where such events occurred were [[extinction|made extinct]], being replaced abruptly by the new forms whose fossils defined the geological strata. Some catastrophists attempted to relate at least one such change to the Biblical account of [[Noah's flood]].
The concept was first popularised by the early 19th-century French scientist [[Georges Cuvier]], who proposed that new life forms had moved in from other areas after local floods, and avoided religious or metaphysical speculation in his scientific writings.<ref name="McG 3" /><ref name="Rudwick 133" />
==History==
===Geology and biblical beliefs=== {{Main article|history of geology}} In the early development of [[geology]], efforts were made in a predominantly [[Christian]] western society to reconcile biblical narratives of [[Genesis creation myth|Creation]] and the [[Universal Flood Myth#Jewish|universal flood]] with new concepts about the processes which had formed the Earth. The discovery of other ancient flood myths was taken as explaining why the flood story was "stated in scientific methods with surprising frequency among the [[Greeks]]", an example being [[Plutarch]]'s account of the [[Universal Flood Myth#Ogyges|Ogygian flood]].<ref>{{Harvardnb|King|1877|p=450}}</ref>
===Cuvier and the natural theologians=== {{further|Alternatives to Darwinism}}
The leading scientific proponent of catastrophism in the early nineteenth century was the French [[anatomist]] and [[paleontologist]] [[Georges Cuvier]]. His motivation was to explain the patterns of [[extinction]] and [[faunal succession]] that he and others were observing in the [[fossil]] record. While he did speculate that the catastrophe responsible for the most recent extinctions in Eurasia might have been the result of the inundation of low-lying areas by the sea, he did not make any reference to [[Noah's flood]].<ref name="McG 3">{{Harvardnb|McGowan|2001|pp=3–6}}</ref> Nor did he ever make any reference to divine creation as the mechanism by which repopulation occurred following the extinction event. In fact Cuvier, influenced by the ideas of the [[age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] and the intellectual climate of the [[French revolution]], avoided religious or metaphysical speculation in his scientific writings.<ref name="Rudwick 133">{{Harvnb|Rudwick|1972|pp=133–134}}</ref> Cuvier also believed that the [[stratigraphic]] record indicated that there had been several of these revolutions, which he viewed as recurring natural events, amid long intervals of stability during the history of life on earth. This led him to believe the Earth was several million years old.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rudwick|1972|p=131}}</ref>
By contrast in Britain, where [[natural theology]] was influential during the early nineteenth century, a group of geologists including [[William Buckland]] and [[Robert Jameson]] interpreted Cuvier's work differently. Cuvier had written an introduction to a collection of his papers on fossil quadrupeds, discussing his ideas on catastrophic extinction. Jameson translated Cuvier's introduction into English, publishing it under the title ''Theory of the Earth''. He added extensive editorial notes to the translation, explicitly linking the latest of Cuvier's revolutions with the biblical flood. The resulting essay was extremely influential in the English-speaking world.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rudwick|1972|pp=133–135}}</ref> Buckland spent much of his early career trying to demonstrate the reality of the biblical flood using geological evidence. He frequently cited Cuvier's work, even though Cuvier had proposed an inundation of limited geographic extent and extended duration, whereas Buckland, to be consistent with the biblical account, was advocating a universal flood of short duration.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rudwick|1972|p=135}}</ref> Eventually, Buckland abandoned [[flood geology]] in favor of the [[glaciation]] theory advocated by [[Louis Agassiz]], following a visit to the Alps where Agassiz demonstrated the effects of glaciation at first hand. As a result of the influence of Jameson, Buckland, and other advocates of natural theology, the nineteenth century debate over catastrophism took on much stronger religious overtones in Britain than elsewhere in Europe.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rudwick|1972|pp=136–138}}</ref>
===The rise of uniformitarianism in geology=== Uniformitarian explanations for the formation of [[sedimentary rock]] and an understanding of the immense stretch of [[geological time]], or as the concept came to be known [[deep time]], were found in the writing of [[James Hutton]], sometimes known as the father of geology, in the late 18th century. The geologist [[Charles Lyell]] built upon Hutton's ideas during the first half of 19th century and amassed observations in support of the uniformitarian idea that the Earth's features had been shaped by same geological processes that could be observed in the present acting gradually over an immense period of time. Lyell presented his ideas in the influential three volume work, ''[[Principles of Geology]]'', published in the 1830s, which challenged theories about geological cataclysms proposed by proponents of catastrophism like Cuvier and Buckland.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rudwick|1972|pp=174–175}}</ref>
From around 1850 to 1980, most geologists endorsed [[uniformitarianism (science)|uniformitarianism]] ("The present is the key to the past") and [[gradualism]] (''geologic change occurs slowly over long periods of time'') and rejected the idea that cataclysmic events such as [[earthquakes]], [[volcano|volcanic eruptions]], or floods of vastly greater power than those observed at the present time, played any significant role in the formation of the Earth's surface. Instead they believed that the earth had been shaped by the long term action of forces such as volcanism, earthquakes, erosion, and sedimentation, that could still be observed in action today. In part, the geologists' rejection was fostered by their impression that the catastrophists of the early nineteenth century believed that God was directly involved in determining the history of Earth. Some of the theories about Catastrophism in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries were connected with [[religion]] and catastrophic origins were sometimes considered [[Miracle|miraculous]] rather than natural events.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rudwick|1972|pp=174–179}}</ref>
The rise in uniformitarianism made the introduction of a new catastrophe theory very difficult. In 1923 [[J Harlen Bretz]] published a paper on the [[channeled scablands]] formed by glacial [[Lake Missoula]] in Washington State, USA. Bretz encountered resistance to his theories from the geology establishment of the day, kicking off an acrimonious 40 year debate. Finally in 1979 Bretz received the [[Penrose Medal]]; the [[Geological Society of America]]'s highest award.<ref>[http://www.geosociety.org/awards/past.htm Penrose Medal 1979] to J Harlen Bretz, [[Geological Society of America]]</ref>
===Immanuel Velikovsky's views=== {{Main|Velikovskyism}} In the 1950s, [[Immanuel Velikovsky]] propounded catastrophism in several popular books. He speculated that the planet [[Venus]] is a former "[[comet]]" which was ejected from [[Jupiter]] and subsequently 3,500 years ago made two catastrophic close passes by Earth, 52 years apart, and later interacted with Mars, which then had a series of near collisions with Earth which ended in 687 BCE, before settling into its current [[orbit]]. Velikovsky used this to explain the biblical [[Ten Plagues|plague]]s of [[Egypt]], the biblical reference to the "Sun standing still" for a day (Joshua 10:12 & 13, explained by changes in Earth's rotation), and the sinking of [[Atlantis]]. Scientists vigorously rejected Velikovsky's conjectures.<ref name="UnMuseum">{{cite web |last1=Krystek |first1=Lee |title=Venus in the Corner Pocket: The Controversial Theories of Immanuel Velikovsky |url=http://www.unmuseum.org/velikov.htm |publisher=Museum of Unnatural Mystery |accessdate=2007-12-14}}</ref>
==Current application== Neocatastrophism is the explanation of sudden extinctions in the palaeontological record by high magnitude, low frequency events (such as asteroid impacts, super-volcanic eruptions, supernova gamma ray bursts, etc.), as opposed to the more prevalent [[Geomorphology|geomorphological]] thought which emphasises low magnitude, high frequency events.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Goudie |first1=A. |year= |title=Encyclopedia of Geomorphology |page=709 |publisher= |isbn= }}</ref>
===Luis Alvarez impact event hypothesis=== {{Main|Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event}}
Over the past 25 years, a scientifically based catastrophism has gained wide acceptance with regard to certain events in the distant past. One impetus for this change came from the publication of a historic paper by [[Walter Alvarez|Walter]] and [[Luis Walter Alvarez|Luis Alvarez]] in 1980. This paper suggested that a {{convert|10|km|mi}} [[asteroid]] [[Impact event|struck Earth]] 66 million years ago at the end of the [[Cretaceous]] period. The impact wiped out about 70% of all species, including the [[dinosaur]]s, leaving behind the [[Cretaceous–Paleogene boundary]] (K–T boundary). In 1990, a {{convert|180|km|mi}} candidate crater marking the impact was identified at [[Chicxulub Crater|Chicxulub]] in the [[Yucatán Peninsula]] of [[Mexico]].
Since then, the debate about the [[extinction]] of the dinosaurs and other [[mass extinction]] events has centered on whether the extinction mechanism was the asteroid impact, widespread volcanism (which occurred about the same time), or some other mechanism or combination. Most of the mechanisms suggested are catastrophic in nature.
The observation of the [[Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9|Shoemaker-Levy 9]] cometary collision with Jupiter illustrated that catastrophic events occur as natural events.
===Comparison with uniformitarianism=== One of the key differences between catastrophism and uniformitarianism is that uniformitarianism requires the assumption of vast timelines, whereas catastrophism does not. Today most geologists combine catastrophist and uniformitarianist standpoints, taking the view that [[History of Earth|Earth's history]] is a slow, gradual story punctuated by occasional natural catastrophic events that have affected Earth and its inhabitants.<ref>{{cite book |last1= |first1= |year=2007 |chapter=Uniformitarianism |chapterurl=http://www.bartleby.com/65/un/uniformi.html |title=The Columbia Encyclopedia |edition=6th |publisher=[[Columbia University Press]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060624122338/http://www.bartleby.com/65/un/uniformi.html |archivedate=2006-06-24 |df= }}</ref>
===Moon-formation=== {{Main|Giant impact theory}} Modern theories also suggest that Earth's anomalously large [[moon]] was formed catastrophically. In a paper published in ''Icarus'' in 1975, [[William K. Hartmann]] and [[Donald R. Davis]] proposed that a catastrophic near-miss by a large [[planetesimal]] early in Earth's formation approximately 4.5 billion years ago blew out rocky debris, remelted Earth and formed the [[Moon]], thus explaining the Moon's lesser density and lack of an iron core.<ref>{{cite journal |last2=Gott III |first=J. R. |year=2005 |title=Where Did The Moon Come From? |journal= [[The Astronomical Journal]] |volume= 129 | issue=3 | pages= 1724–1745 |arxiv=astro-ph/0405372 |bibcode=2005AJ....129.1724B |doi=10.1086/427539 |last1=Belbruno |first2=J. Richard}}</ref> The impact theory does have some faults; some computer simulations show the formation of a ring or multiple moons post impact, and elements are not quite the same between the earth and moon.<ref>{{cite web |last1= |first1= |date=September 2009 |title=Moonwalk |url=http://www.geolsoc.org.uk/webdav/site/GSL/shared/pdfs/Geoscientist/Download%20PDF%20copy%20of%20Geoscientist%2019.9%20September%202009.pdf |publisher=[[Geological Society of London]] |accessdate=2010-03-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Binder |first1=A.B. |year=1974 |title=On the origin of the Moon by rotational fission |journal=[[The Moon]] |volume=11 |issue=2 |pages=53–76 |bibcode=1974Moon...11...53B |doi=10.1007/BF01877794}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1= Stevenson |first1=D. J. |year=1987 |title=Origin of the Moon-The Collision Hypothesis |journal=Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences |volume= 15|issue= |pages= 271–315|bibcode=1987AREPS..15..271S |doi=10.1146/annurev.ea.15.050187.001415 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Alternatives to Darwinism]] * [[Flood basalt]] * [[Glacial lake outburst flood]] * [[History of geology]] * [[History of paleontology]] * [[Megatsunami]] * [[Pensée (Immanuel Velikovsky Reconsidered)]] * [[Punctuated equilibrium]] * [[Supervolcano]] * [[Uniformitarianism (science)|Uniformitarianism]] * [[Volcanic winter]] * [[Zanclean flood]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Sources==

S. Rudwick |last=Rudwick |first=Martin J. S. |title=The Meaning of Fossils |location=Chicago, Illinois |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=1972 |isbn=0-226-73103-0 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=McGowan |first=Christopher |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vC4c3Kx746QC |title=The Dragon Seekers |location=Cambridge, Massachusetts |publisher=Perseus Publishing |year=2001 |isbn=0-7382-0282-7 |ref=harv}}
==Further reading==
* Lewin, R.; ''Complexity'', Dent, London, 1993, p. 75 * Palmer, T.; ''Catastrophism, Neocatastrophism and Evolution''. Society for Interdisciplinary Studies in association with Nottingham Trent University, 1994, {{ISBN|0-9514307-1-8}} (SIS) {{ISBN|0-905488-20-2}} (Nottingham Trent University)
==External links== *[http://www.pibburns.com/catastro/extinct.htm Catastrophism and Mass Extinctions] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20010108121600/http://science.ntu.ac.uk/life/staff/tp/fallc.htm The Fall and Rise of Catastrophism] *[http://www.psi.edu/projects/moon/moon.html "The origin of the moon'.] *[http://www.catastrophism.com/ Catastrophism! Man, Myth and Mayhem in Ancient History and the Sciences] *[http://www.answersincreation.org/catastrophism.htm Answers In Creation - Catastrophism Article] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060909180136/http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/cgi-local/DHI/dhi.cgi?id=dv4-56 ''Dictionary of the History of Ideas'':] "Uniformitarianism and Catastrophism"
