revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{about|the opera|the painter who is its subject|Charlotte Salomon}} [[file:Charlotte Salomon 0929 Michelides.jpg|thumb|''Charlotte Salomon'', World Premiere at the [[Salzburg Festival]] 2014]] '''''Charlotte Salomon''''' is an opera by [[Marc-André Dalbavie]]. The libretto is by [[Barbara Honigmann]] (portions translated into French by Johannes Honigmann) who based much of it on [[Charlotte Salomon]]'s [[autobiographical]] and [[wikt:Special:Search/posthumous|posthumous]] work ''Leben? Oder Theater?''Rebecca Schmid, "Reanimating a Life and an Art Cut Short," ''New York Times'' (July 26, 2014). The opera was first performed at the [[Salzburg Festival]] on July 28, 2014.[http://oe1.orf.at/programm/378856 "Marc Andre Dalbavie: 'Charlotte Salomon'" Österreichischer Rundfunk.] == Composition == The nature of ''Leben? Oder Theater?'' is of an artist fashioning her own life into an artistic creation. Dalbavie said that the "intrinsically musical and even cinematic qualities of 'Leben? Oder Theater?'" combined with an attraction to real-life drama inspired him to compose an opera based on Charlotte Salomon. Since Salomon was aiming for a form of communication that combined various arts, Dalbalvie felt that her story needed music. He was quoted as saying "She recreated her life through a work of art." Just as Dalbavie's opera ''Gesualdo'' (based on the life of [[Carlo Gesualdo]]) incorporates portions of his subject's compositions, so too does Dalbavie incorporate existing music into his opera, such as the "Habañera" from [[Georges Bizet|Bizet]]'s ''[[Carmen]]'' and "Wir winden dir den Jungfernkranz" from [[Carl Maria von Weber|Weber]]'s ''[[Der Freischütz]]''. The opera includes a character representing the author Charlotte Salomon (speaking role), and also her fictive creation, named Charlotte Kann ([[mezzo-soprano]]). While the opera (including the role of Charlotte Kann) is sung in French, the character named Charlotte Salomon comments on the action in German. By the end of the opera, the languages are reversed, representing the integration of the artist her subject. Dalbavie's orchestrations derives from his analysis of the human voice's acoustic frequencies, a technique used in [[spectral music]] as well as alluding to a singing teacher's character in the opera. Dalbavie described the scoring of the opera—for 65 orchestral musicians (the size of the Salzburg Mozarteum Orchestra)—as one designed not as much for dramatic impact as for "maximum tonal richness." == Premiere == ''Charlotte Salomon'' is in two acts and an epilogue. It was first performed at the [[Salzburg Festival]] on July 28, 2014, where it was directed by [[Luc Bondy]]. The production involved twenty projections of Salomon's artwork. ==Roles== {| class="wikitable" !Role !!Voice type !!Premiere Cast, July 28, 2014
Conductor: Marc-André Dalbavie |- |Charlotte Salomon ||speaking role ||[[Johanna Wokalek]] |- |Charlotte Kann ||Mezzo-soprano || [[Marianne Crebassa]] |- |Frau Knarre, her grandmother ||Mezzo-soprano || [[Cornelia Kallisch]] |- |Franziska Kann, her mother / A woman ||Mezzo-soprano ||Géraldine Chauvet |- |Paulinka Bimbam, a singer, her stepmother ||Mezzo-soprano || Anaik Morel |- |Amadeus Daberlohn, a singing teacher ||Tenor ||Frédéric Antoun |- |Herr Knarre / Fourth Nazi ||Bass-Baritone ||Vincent LeTexier |- |Doktor Kann, a doctor, her father / First emigrant ||Baritone || Jean Sébastien Bou |- |Professor Klingklang / An art student / Second Nazi / Policeman ||Baritone || Michal Partyka |- |Art teacher / The Minister of Propaganda / First Nazi / A man / Second emigrant ||Tenor || [[Éric Huchet]] |- |An art student from Tirol ||Mezzo-soprano ||Annika Schlicht |- |Third Nazi ||Baritone || Wolfgang Resch |- |} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Operas]] [[Category:Historical operas]] [[Category:2014 operas]] [[Category:French-language operas]] [[Category:German-language operas]] [[Category:Operas set in France]] [[Category:Operas set in Germany]]

{{Infobox film | name = The Almería Case | image = El caso Almería poster.jpg | alt = | caption = | film name = El caso Almería | director = [[Pedro Costa Musté]] | producer = Multivideo S.A. | writer = | screenplay = Manolo Marinero, Pedro Costa Musté, Nereida B. Arnau | story = | based on = | starring = | narrator = | music = Ricardo Miralles | cinematography = José Luis Alcaine | editing = | studio = | distributor = | released = {{film date|1984|01|26|Spain}} | runtime = 120 minutes | country = Spain | language = Spanish | budget = | gross = }} '''''El caso Almería''''' (English: The Almería Case) is a [[1984 in film|1984]] [[Spain|Spanish]] film directed by [[Pedro Costa Musté]].
== Plot ==
The film tells the story of three men tortured and killed by [[Guardia Civil]] in 1981.
== Cast ==
* [[Agustín González]] * [[Fernando Guillén (actor)|Fernando Guillén]] * [[Manuel Alexandre]] * Margarita Calahorra * Iñaki Miramón * Pedro Díaz del Corral * [[Antonio Banderas]] * Juan Echanove

Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2600:387:6:80F:0:0:0:C4|2600:387:6:80F:0:0:0:C4]] identified as test/vandalism using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Original research|date=December 2010}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2010}} }}
The '''first haircut''' for a human has special significance in certain cultures and religions. It can be considered a [[rite of passage]] or a [[milestone]].
==Indian babies==
===Hindu babies=== {{Main|Chudakarana}}
In [[Hindu]] tradition, the hair from birth is associated with undesirable traits from past lives. Thus at the time of the [[Mundan ceremony|mundan]], the child is freshly shaven to signify freedom from the past and moving into the future. It is also said that the shaving of the hair stimulates proper growth of the brain and nerves, and that the [[sikha]], a tuft at the crown of the head, protects the memory.<ref>It is believed to wash away bad karma and give the recipient good karma and a better life than their previous life, from [http://hinducouncil.net/index.php/religion Hindu Council UK] web page on the mundan ceremony</ref> hours
[[Hindus]] practice a variety of rituals from birth to death. Collectively these are known as ''[[saṃskāra]]s'', meaning rites of purification, and are believed to make the body pure and fit for worship. A boy's first haircut, known as ''choula'', is one such samskara and is considered an event of great auspiciousness. The lawbooks or ''smritis'' prescribe that a boy must have his haircut in his first or third year. While complete [[tonsure]] is common, some Hindus prefer to leave some hair on the head, distinguishing this rite from the inauspicious tonsure that occurs upon the death of a parent. Those that practice complete tonsure generally ritually offer the hair to their family deity. Many travel to temples such as the famed [[Tirumala Venkateswara Temple]] of Lord [[Vishnu]] to perform this ceremony.
Traditionally, a Hindu girl never has her hair cut after the first haircut which generally happens at the age of 11 months; So the first haircut for the girl is very important because that is the only time they do. However, some Hindus practice a tonsure ceremony for girls as well. The details vary by sect, locality, family, and country.
And also old timer Hindu people said that a newborn baby should bald their hair as cannot be with newborn hair for so long as it was a sign of a bad luck. Most of the people will bald their babies hair in the age of 3-5 months and Hindu also follow odd months to do.(Revathy)
In some Brahmin households, a baby girl's hair is never shaved.
===Maliku babies=== At the twentieth day from birth, [[Minicoy Island|Maliku]] babies' heads are shaven and the hair is weighed against gold or silver, which is given to the poor. The ceremony is called ''boabeylun''.
==Mongolian babies== Mongolian children get their first haircut in early ages between 2-5. Depending on the lunar calendar, boys receive their first hair cut in their even year and girls in odd year. The ritual of cutting the first hair is called Daah' Urgeeh. It is a big occasion for a whole family when guests are invited. Each guest cuts a strand of hair, saying his wishes to the child, and gives a gift.
==Orthodox Jews==
===Orthodox boys=== {{Main|Upsherin}}
Many [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] and [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]] Jewish boys get their first haircut when they are three years old. The hair-cutting ceremony is known in [[Yiddish]] as the ''upsherenish'' or ''[[upsherin]]'' (shear off), and in Hebrew "halaqah" (smoothing).
In [[Israel]], there are also non-religious families who adhere to this custom and do not cut their sons' hair until the age of three. A mass hair cutting ceremony is held on the holiday of [[Lag Ba'omer]] at the tomb of Rabbi [[Simeon bar Yohai]] in the [[Galilee|Galilean]] town of [[Meron (Israel)|Meron]].
==Slavic culture==
===Polish===
The ritual first haircut ({{lang-pl|postrzyżyny}}) was a pre-Christian, all-Slavic tradition, though it survived in Poland well into the 18th century. This first haircut traditionally took place between the ages of 7 and 10, and was conducted by either the boy's father or a stranger, who would thus enter into the boy's family.<ref name="leciejewicz-303">{{cite encyclopedia |author1=Zbigniew Bukowski |editor=Lech Leciejewicz |encyclopedia=Mały słownik kultury dawnych Słowian |title=Postrzyżyny |url= |edition=2 |year=1988 |publisher=Wiedza Powszechna |volume= |location=Warsaw |isbn=8321404995 |page=303 |language=pl}}</ref> Before that age the boy's life was connected to his mother and he was treated as a child. The ritual haircut, coupled with the granting of an additional given name (usually the third), marked the boy's coming of age and a transition to the world of men, in which he was to be looked after by his father.<ref name="kostrzewski-419">{{cite book |author1=Józef Kostrzewski |coauthors= |editor1= |others= |title=Kultura prapolska |trans-title=Ancient Polish culture |url= |edition=3 |series= |volume= |year=1962 |publisher=[[Państwowe Wydawnictwo Naukowe]] |location=Warsaw |id=PB 1008/63 |oclc= |page=303 |language=pl}}</ref> The ritual also constituted the father's formal act of recognition of the boy as a son.<ref name="kostrzewski-419"/>
===Ukrainian=== [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] babies often have their hair cut on their first birthday as part of the ancient ''Postryzhennya'' custom.<ref>[http://pages.prodigy.net/l.hodges/haircut.htm ''Postryzhennya'' - The Haircutting] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051217135301/http://pages.prodigy.net/l.hodges/haircut.htm |date=2005-12-17 }} there are doubts on the reliability of the source</ref>
==Polynesian boys== In [[Cook Islands]] tradition, the haircutting ceremony is a rite of passage for young boys. At these large gatherings the boy sits on a chair draped with ''[[tivaivai|tīvaevae]]'' (quilts). As his hair is cut, members of the community plaster the boy with money or other gifts. The custom serves to maintain reciprocal ties within the extended family and community.<ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/cook-islanders/2/3 Cook Islanders - Haircutting ceremony, Porirua - Te Ara Encyclopedia of New Zealand]</ref>
Traditionally, [[Niue]]an boys do not cut their hair, which is lovingly cared for by sisters, mothers and fathers . When the boys become teenagers, a ceremony is held where women tend the hair for the last time before it is cut. Members of the extended family plaster the youth with banknotes – all part of a large informal Niuean economy that links families and ensures the community looks after its own.<ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/niueans/1/6 Niueans - A young Niuean at his hair-cutting ceremony - Te Ara Encyclopedia of New Zealand]</ref>
==North American babies== ===Native American babies=== Some [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] tribes commemorated the first haircut with a ritualistic dance. The [[Apache]] tribe had a springtime ritual.
===African Caribbean boys=== Within the [[wikt:Afro-Caribbean|African Caribbean]] community this is performed once the child begins to speak clearly or after the child reaches two. This is usually done in a barbershop or carried out by the parent.
==Yazidi boys== In the [[Yazidi]] tradition (mainly in Iran), the ''bisk'' ceremony involves cutting of a baby boy's two or three first locks, according to old traditions by his 40th day after birth to be given to the family's [[shaikh]] and [[Islam Pir|pir]], but in modern practice at 7 to 11 months, and kept by the family. The bisk ceremony is regarded as the central initiatory ritual by most Yazidis from Turkey, Armenia. and Syria. In the European Diaspora, the term is often translated as ''baptism.'' The ceremony is reminiscent of the [[Muslim]] [['aqiqa]] celebrated on the seventh day after birth, but the Yazidi ceremony takes place at a later stage, when the child has already been named.
==See also== *[[Tonsure]], traditional practice of Christian churches of cutting or shaving the hair from the scalp (while leaving some parts uncut) of clerics, monastics, and, in the Eastern Orthodox Church, all baptized members.
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.hairarchives.com/private/haircutnew.htm The First Haircut] *[http://www.sunsetbeacon.com/archives/richmondreview/2005editions/Jun05/ChineseTraditions.html Family Celebrations at Heart of Many Chinese Traditions]
{{DEFAULTSORT:First Haircut}} [[Category:Ceremonies]] [[Category:Hairdressing]] [[Category:Rites of passage]]

BD2412 moved page [[Horatio Seymour presidential campaign, 1868]] to [[Horatio Seymour 1868 presidential campaign]]: Per [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (government and legislation)#Proposed change to election/referendum naming format]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox U.S. federal election campaign | committee = Horatio Seymour for President | logo = [[File:Seymour-Blair.png|250px]] | campaign = [[United States presidential election, 1868|U.S. presidential election, 1868]] | candidate = {{ubl|[[Horatio Seymour]]|[[Francis Preston Blair Jr.]]}} | status = Lost general election | key_people = | affiliation = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] | headquarters = | receipts = }} In 1868, the [[USA Democrats|Democrats]] nominated former [[New York Governor]] [[Horatio Seymour]] for [[POTUS|President]] and [[Francis Preston Blair Jr.]] (a [[U.S. House of Representatives|Representative]] from [[Missouri]]) for [[VPOTUS|Vice President]].<ref name="harpweek1">{{cite web|url=http://elections.harpweek.com/1868/Overview-1868-2.htm |title=HarpWeek | Elections | 1868 Overview (Page 2)|publisher=Elections.harpweek.com |date= |accessdate=August 18, 2018}}</ref> The Seymour-Blair ticket ran on a platform which supported national reconciliation and [[states' rights]], opposed [[Reconstruction era|Reconstruction]], and opposed both Black equality and Black suffrage. Meanwhile, the Republican presidential ticket led by General Ulysses S. Grant benefited from Grant's status as a war hero (for winning the American Civil War) and ran on a pro-Reconstruction (and pro-Fourteenth Amendment) platform. Ultimately, the Seymour-Blair ticket ended up losing to the Republican ticket of [[U.S. General|General]] [[Ulysses S. Grant]] and [[House Speaker]] [[Schuyler Colfax]] in the [[1868 U.S. presidential election]].<ref name="harpweek1"/>
==Background== [[File:President Andrew Johnson.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Andrew Johnson was the incumbent U.S. President in 1868 and made an unsuccessful bid for the 1868 Democratic presidential nomination.]] [[File:Mathew Brady, Portrait of Secretary of the Treasury Salmon P. Chase, officer of the United States government (1860–1865).jpg|thumb|left|200px|United States Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase was a prominent early contender for the 1868 Democratic presidential nomination.]] [[File:GeorgeHPendleton.png|thumb|right|200px|1864 Democratic vice-presidential nominee George Pendleton initially led in the delegate count at the 1868 Democratic National Convention.]] [[File:WinfieldSHancock.png|thumb|left|200px|For a time, General Winfield Scott Hancock led in the balloting at the 1868 Democratic National Convention.]] [[File:Horatio Seymour - Brady-Handysmall.jpg|thumb|right|200px|1868 Democratic presidential nominee and former New York Governor Horatio Seymour.]] [[File:George Wythe McCook painting.JPG|thumb|left|200px|George McCook nominated Horatio Seymour as a compromise candidate for the Democrats in 1868.]] [[File:Ulysses S. Grant 1870-1880.jpg|thumb|right|200px|1868 Republican presidential nominee and former Union General Ulysses S. Grant.]] [[File:ElectoralCollege1868.svg|thumb|left|200px|A map of the results of the 1868 U.S. presidential election. In this election, Grant decisively won the electoral vote.]] The 1868 election occurred three years after the end of the [[American Civil War]] and less than a year after [[POTUS|President]] [[Andrew Johnson]]'s [[Andrew Johnson's impeachment|impeachment]] (Johnson failed to get convicted by one vote).<ref name="harpweek2">{{cite web|url=http://elections.harpweek.com/1868/Overview-1868-1.htm |title=HarpWeek | Elections | 1868 Overview (Page 1)|publisher=Elections.harpweek.com |date= |accessdate=August 18, 2018}}</ref> In addition, during the 1868 campaign season, the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]] was ratified in order to secure basic rights for newly freed African-Americans.<ref name="harpweek2"/> Some controversy was generated due to the fact that the [[GOP|Republican]] [[U.S. Congress]] made ratification of the Fourteenth Amendment a precondition for the former [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] states to rejoin the Union.<ref name="harpweek2"/>
==The run-up to the 1868 Democratic National Convention== After the 1866 elections, some prominent Democrats considered nominating [[General]] Ulysses S. Grant as the Democratic nominee for U.S. President in 1868.<ref name="harpweek2"/> However, this idea was dropped after Grant made it clear that he did not want to be associated with the Democratic Party.<ref name="harpweek2"/> The Democrats then turned to their 1864 Vice Presidential nominee and former [[Ohio]] [[Congressman]] [[George H. Pendleton]].<ref name="harpweek2"/> Pendleton – the initial frontrunner for the 1868 Democratic presidential nomination<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.php?id=14402 |title=H-Net Reviews |publisher=H-net.org |date= |accessdate=September 22, 2018}}</ref> – was a principled opponent of U.S. President [[Abraham Lincoln]] during the American Civil War, was noted for his intelligence and civility, and had a lot of support in the [[Western United States]].<ref name="harpweek2"/> What ultimately doomed Pendleton's bid was his "soft money views" and specifically his support of printing more money in order to spur inflation so that debtors can have some relief.<ref name="harpweek2"/> Thus, some Democrats searched for a "hard money" alternative (specifically someone who supported the [[gold standard]]) to Pendleton – with Indiana Senator [[Thomas A. Hendricks]] being a possible contender for this role.<ref name="harpweek2"/>
Another prominent candidate for the 1868 Democratic presidential nomination was [[United States Chief Justice|Chief Justice]] [[Salmon P. Chase]].<ref name="harpweek2"/> While Chase won the support of Democrats such as Congressmen [[S. S. "Sunset" Cox]] of [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[Daniel W. Voorhees|Daniel Voorhees]] of [[Indiana]], what ultimately doomed his bid was his support of [[Black suffrage|Black manhood suffrage]] and other basic rights for [[African-Americans]].<ref name="harpweek2"/> Other Democratic presidential candidates in 1868 included Senator [[James Rood Doolittle|James Doolittle]] of [[Wisconsin]], [[Governor]] [[Joel Parker]] of [[New Jersey]], [[Governor]] [[James E. English|James English]] of [[Connecticut]], General [[Winfield Scott Hancock]] of [[Pennsylvania]] (who ultimately ended up becoming the Democratic presidential nominee in [[United States presidential election, 1880|1880]]), former [[Lieutenant Governor]] [[Sanford Church]] of New York, and former Congressman and [[railroad]] president [[Asa Packer]] of Pennsylvania.<ref name="harpweek2"/> In addition, incumbent U.S. President Andrew Johnson attempted to secure conservative support for getting the 1868 Democratic presidential nomination.<ref name="harpweek2"/> However, many of President Johnson's initial supporters abandoned him as a result of his 1868 impeachment.<ref name="harpweek2"/>
==The 1868 Democratic National Convention== On July 4, 1868, the [[1868 Democratic National Convention]] opened in the new [[Tammany Hall]] building in [[New York City]].<ref name="harpweek2"/> New York Governor Horatio Seymour, who first supported Thomas A. Hendricks and then Salmon P. Chase for the 1868 Democratic presidential nomination,<ref name="harpweek1"/> was selected as the chairman of this convention.<ref name="harpweek2"/> The 1868 Democratic Party platform accepted the demise of both [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|slavery]] and [[secession]], but also demanded the end of Reconstruction by calling for the return of authority to the states, the non-renewal of the [[Freedmen’s Bureau]], [[Pardons for ex-Confederates|amnesty for all former Confederates]], and the withdrawal of the [[U.S. military]] from the [[Southern United States]].<ref name="harpweek2"/> The platform also accused the Republicans – "the Radical party" – of violating the constitutional rights of the Southern states and of subjecting them to "military despotism and Negro supremacy."<ref name="harpweek2"/>
On the first ballot, George Pendleton led with 105 votes to President Johnson's 65, Sanford Church's 34, and General Hancock's 33.5.<ref name="harpweek2"/> For the next several ballots, Pendleton increased his support among the delegates while Hancock moved into a distant second place and while Hendricks moved into third place.<ref name="harpweek2"/> Meanwhile, support for President Johnson dwindled until it disappeared on the 14th ballot.<ref name="harpweek2"/> On the seventh and eighth ballots, Pendleton peaked at 156.5 delegates – which caused New York's delegation to switch their support from favorite son Sanford Church to Thomas Hendricks.<ref name="harpweek2"/> As Pendleton's support collapsed, Hendricks took the lead for a while but was unable to sustain it after General Winfield Scott Hancock's home state of Pennsylvania added its delegates to his column – thus allowing Hancock to overtake Hendricks and to take the lead for the first time.<ref name="harpweek2"/> Ultimately, Hancock led through the 21st ballot.<ref name="harpweek1"/> Meanwhile, Salmon Chase’s name was put into nomination on the 17th ballot and George Pendleton’s name was withdrawn on the 18th ballot.<ref name="harpweek1"/>
On the 22nd ballot, General [[George McCook]] nominated former New York Governor Horatio Seymour, causing spontaneous cheering and demonstrations of approval.<ref name="harpweek1"/> Seymour did not want the nomination and thus declined it, but the delegates unanimously nominated him anyway.<ref name="harpweek1"/> For Seymour's running mate, the delegates unanimously voted for Missouri Congressman [[Francis Preston Blair Jr.]] (also known as Frank Blair Jr.).<ref name="harpweek1"/>
==Campaign== The 1868 Republican presidential nominee, General Ulysses S. Grant, did not openly campaign and instead left the job to surrogates.<ref name="harpweek1"/> Grant's surrogates gave stump [[speeches]], circulated campaign [[pamphlets]] and political broadsides, rallied the voters with [[barbecues]] and torchlight [[parades]], and organized into pro-Grant clubs like the Tanners and the Boys in Blue.<ref name="harpweek1"/> The Republicans based their campaign on being the party that saved the Union, ended slavery, and began reforming the South.<ref name="harpweek1"/> They argued that the election of a Democratic President would result in gridlock which would hamper [[Reconstruction era|Reconstruction]].<ref name="harpweek1"/> Meanwhile, the Democrats argued that Republicans were in favor of Black equality or even Black superiority not only in the Southern U.S., but throughout the entire United States.<ref name="harpweek1"/> They also attacked the Republican-backed military rule in the Southern U.S. and argued that they were the only truly national party and thus the only party that could bring national reconciliation.<ref name="harpweek1"/> The Democrats also attacked Grant as being "a besotted, uncouth, simple-minded, unprincipled, Negro-loving tyrant."<ref name="harpweek1"/>
As a result of the Democrats' feeling of hopelessness, Horatio Seymour--the 1868 Democratic presidential nominee – engaged in a speaking tour near the end of the 1868 campaign.<ref name="harpweek1"/> On October 21, Seymour spoke in [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]] and later traveled to [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Pittsburgh]], [[Cleveland]], [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], [[Detroit]], [[Indianapolis]], and [[Chicago]].<ref name="harpweek1"/> However, the lackluster tone and repetitiveness of Seymour's speeches did not help his case (though these speeches were praised by Democratic [[newspapers]]) and it also did not help Seymour that his running mate Blair was a loose cannon who made various [[gaffes]] – such as predicting that a Grant Presidency would transform the U.S. into a military dictatorship.<ref name="harpweek1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abrahamlincolncartoons.info/SubPages/Biography.php?UniqueID=8 |title=HarpWeek | Abraham Lincoln Cartoons |publisher=Abrahamlincolncartoons.info |date= |accessdate=September 22, 2018}}</ref>
==Results== In the U.S. presidential election on November 3, 1868, Ulysses S. Grant defeated Horatio Seymour in the popular vote by a 53% to 47% margin and in the electoral vote by a margin of 214 to 80.<ref name="harpweek1"/> 78% of the American electorate participated in this election – including 500,000 African-American men who voted for the first time in this election.<ref name="harpweek1"/> While Seymour lost the election, there were some bright spots for him.<ref name="harpweek1"/> Specifically, he won New Jersey, New York and [[Oregon]] and almost won [[California]].<ref name="harpweek1"/> In addition, Seymour won [[Kentucky]], [[Maryland]], and [[Delaware]].<ref name="harpweek1"/> In addition, it is worth noting that Grant only managed to win the popular vote in 1868 as a result of Black suffrage.<ref name="worldhistory1">{{cite web|url=https://worldhistory.us/american-history/ulysses-s-grant-elected-in-1868-thanks-to-black-suffrage-in-the-south.php |title=Ulysses S. Grant Elected in 1868 Thanks to Black Suffrage in the South | World History |publisher=Worldhistory.us |date=July 4, 2017 |accessdate=September 22, 2018}}</ref> Historian Paul F. Boller, Jr. wrote that "[i]t is apparent that if [Grant] had not won the 450,000 to 500,000 votes cast by the freedmen in the Southern states under military occupation, he would not have won his popular majority."<ref name="worldhistory1"/>
In spite of the fact that Grant won the 1868 election, the Republicans largely lost interest in Reconstruction within the next several years – thus paving the way for the eventual emergence of the [[Jim Crow]] South.<ref name="harpweek1"/> On the bright side, the Republicans' victory (with the help of African-American voters) in 1868 motivated them to pass and ratify the [[Fifteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution|Fifteenth Amendment]] which forbade discrimination in regards to the suffrage based on race, color, or former condition of servitude (though this Amendment was later largely circumvented in the former Confederate states through things such as [[poll taxes]] (including [[grandfather clauses]]) and [[literacy tests]]).<ref name="harpweek1"/> This is a notable development since, just a couple of years earlier, Republicans had refused to guarantee African-American suffrage in the Fourteenth Amendment due to their belief and fear that this will prevent the Fourteenth Amendment from being ratified.<ref>{{cite web|author=Raoul Berger |url=http://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/berger-government-by-judiciary-the-transformation-of-the-fourteenth-amendment |title=Government by Judiciary: The Transformation of the Fourteenth Amendment - Online Library of Liberty |publisher=Oll.libertyfund.org |date= |accessdate=September 22, 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Democratic presidential campaigns}}

page.title: International Symposium on Circuits and Systems

revision.comment: Added information about ISCAS 2017 & 2018, corrected grammar problems and edited language labeling ISCAS as an "academic" conference
revision.text:
{{2p|date=March 2017}} {{peacock|date=October 2011}}
{{Redirect|ISCAS||Institute of Software, Chinese Academy of Sciences}} Initiated in 1968, by a small group of distinguished circuit theorists, '''''IEEE''' ISCAS'' has grown into a premier annual conference reflecting the diversity, richness, and significance of the circuits and systems fields, as well as the growing technological applications and [[knowledge economy]] that is based on circuits and systems fundamentals. It is the flagship annual conference of the [[IEEE Circuits and Systems Society]], one of the oldest technical societies of IEEE with approximately 10,000 members worldwide. ISCAS attracts a strong international presence and welcomes technical contributions and participation from all researchers and practitioners in the field of circuits and systems.
ISCAS 2012 was held from May 20 through 23, 2012 in Seoul whose proceedings included about 850 papers.
ISCAS 2013 was held from May 19 through 23, 2013 in Beijing
ISCAS 2014 was held from June 1 through 5, 2014 in Melbourne
ISCAS 2015 was held from May 24 through 27, 2015 in Lisbon
ISCAS 2016 was held from May 22 through 25, 2016 in Montreal
ISCAS 2017 will be held from May 28 through 31, 2017 in Baltimore
== See also == *[[International Solid-State Circuits Conference]] *[[Custom Integrated Circuits Conference]] *[[Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits]]
== External links == *[http://iscas2018.org Web site for ISCAS 2018, in Florence] *[http://iscas2017.org Web site for ISCAS 2017, in Baltimore] *[http://www.iscas2016.org Web site for ISCAS 2016, in Montreal] *[http://www.iscas2015.org Web site for ISCAS 2015, in Lisbon] *[http://www.iscas2014.org Web site for ISCAS 2014, in Melbourne] {{IEEE conferences}} {{DEFAULTSORT:International Symposium On Circuits And Systems}} [[Category:Academic conferences]] [[Category:Technology conferences]] [[Category:IEEE conferences]] {{engineering-stub}}

page.title: Les Amours de la reine Élisabeth

revision.comment: added [[Category:French black-and-white films]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{onesource|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox film | name = Les Amours de la reine Élisabeth | image = Les Amours de la reine Élisabeth.jpg | image_size = | caption = Still from the film, showing Tellegen and Bernhardt | director = [[Louis Mercanton]]
[[Henri Desfontaines]] | producer = Louis Mercanton | writer = [[Émile Moreau (playwright)|Émile Moreau]]
(original play and script) | starring = [[Sarah Bernhardt]]
[[Lou Tellegen]] | music = [[Joseph Carl Breil]] | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = L'Histrionic Film (France)
[[Famous Players Film Company]] (USA) | released = {{Film date|1912|07|12|United States premiere|1912|08||France}} | runtime = 53 minutes (France)
44 minutes (Video version) (USA) | country = France | budget = | gross = }} [[File:Les Amours de la reine Élisabeth (1912).webm|thumb|thumbtime=1|''Les Amours de la reine Élisabeth'']] '''''Les Amours de la reine Élisabeth''''' (''The Loves of Queen Elizabeth''), '''''Les Amours d'Elisabeth, Reine d'Angleterre''''' (''The Loves of Elizabeth, Queen of England'') or '''''La reine Élisabeth''''' (''Queen Elizabeth'') is a 1912 feature 4-reel [[Cinema of France|French]] [[silent film]] based on the love affair between [[Elizabeth I of England]] and the [[Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex|Earl of Essex]]. It was condensed from a play of the same name and directed by [[Louis Mercanton]] and [[Henri Desfontaines]]. It was shot in [[Paris]] and starred [[Sarah Bernhardt]] as Elizabeth and [[Lou Tellegen]] as Essex. Bernhardt by then was 68 and said of the film "This is my last chance at immortality". She and Tellegen were already romantically involved, and this was their second film together. Its production company, L’Histrionic Film, was forced into liquidation by [[Pathé|Pathé Frères]] during the film's production, but it was completed with funds from [[Adolph Zukor]]. Zukor also brought it to [[New York City]], where it premiered at the [[Lyceum Theatre (Broadway)|Lyceum Theatre]] on Broadway. The film’s US release (on State Rights basis, on 12 July 1912) was the first release from the [[Famous Players Film Company]]. Its success convinced other American companies that feature films were commercially viable. Famous Players, which advertised "Famous Players in Famous Plays", later became [[Famous Players-Lasky]], and then [[Paramount Pictures]]. ''Queen Elizabeth'' had one of the earliest dedicated [[film score]]s, composed by [[Joseph Carl Breil]] specifically for the production. Four years earlier, Bernhardt’s first film ''[[The Assassination of the Duke of Guise]]'' (1908), also featured an original film score, one composed by [[Camille Saint-Saëns]].[[Richard Davis (composer)|Davis, Richard]] (1999). ''Complete Guide to Film Scoring'', Berklee Press, Boston. {{ISBN|0-634-00636-3}}, p. 17 ==Cast== *[[Sarah Bernhardt]] as [[Queen Elizabeth I]] *[[Lou Tellegen]] as [[Robert Devereux, Earl of Essex]] *[[Max Maxudian]] as Howard, Earl of Nottingham *[[Nita Romani]] as Arabella, the Countess of Nottingham *[[Jean Angelo]] as Seymour *[[Jean Chameroy]] as [[Lord Bacon]] *[[Albert Decoeur]] as [[Sir Francis Drake]] *[[Georges Deneubourg]] as Biron *[[Marie-Louise Derval]] as Lady Howard *[[Henri Desfontaines]] *[[Guy Favières]] as Worcester *[[Paul Guidé]] as [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] *[[Paul Laurent (actor)|Paul Laurent]] as Jacques Stuart *[[Jane Maylianes]] as Lady Southwell ==See also== *''[[The House That Shadows Built]]'' (1931 promotional film by Paramount) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0002020}} *[http://www.silentera.com/PSFL/data/A/AmoursDeLaReineElisabe1912.html ''Queen Elizabeth'' at SilentEra] *[http://www.britannica.com/eb/art-74539 Clip from the film at ''Encyclopædia Britannica''] {{DEFAULTSORT:Amours de la reine Elisabeth}} [[Category:1912 films]] [[Category:1910s historical films]] [[Category:French historical films]] [[Category:French silent feature films]] [[Category:Films set in Tudor England]] [[Category:Films about Elizabeth I of England]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French black-and-white films]] {{1910s-France-film-stub}}

revision.text:
List of events held in the [[Syracuse metropolitan area|Syracuse, New York metropolitan area]] on an annual basis, by type.
==Art fairs, shows, and galleries== * [http://www.artontheporches.org/ Art on the Porches (Ruskin Ave, Strathmore Neighborhood, Syracuse)] * Syracuse Arts and Crafts Festival * Festival of Trees (Everson Museum) * Gingerbread Gallery (Erie Canal Museum) * Austn Park Annual Art & Craft show/sale, Skaneateles
==Ethnic festivals== * Bavarianfest * [http://www.cnyscots.com/ CNY Scottish Games & Celtic Festival] * New York India Festival - nyindiafestival.wix.com/nyindiafestival * [http://www.cnyscottishgames.org CNY Scottish Games] * Euro Fest * George W. Fowler High School Muticultural Festival * [http://www.greekfest.stsophias.org/ Greek Cultural Festival] * [http://www.syracuseirishfestival.com/ Irish Festival] * [http://www.festaitaliana.bizland.com Italian Festival (La Festa Italiana)] * [http://www.syracusejewishfestival.com/ Jewish Music & Cultural Festival] * Latin American Festival * [http://www.syracusemideastfest.com Middle Eastern Cultural Festival] * [[Oktoberfest]] * [http://www.polishscholarship.com Polish Festival] * Southeast Asian Festival * St. George Macedonian Ethnic Festival * St. John the Baptist Ukrainian Festival * [http://www.stpatricksirishfest.com/ St. Patrick's Irish Festival & Street Fair] * [http://www.stsophias.org St. Sophia's Greek Festival] * [http://www.westcottfair.org/ Westcott Street Cultural Fair]
==Film== * Syracuse International Film Festival
==Food== * [http://rosamondgiffordzoo.org/brew-at-the-zoo Brew At The Zoo (Rosamond Gifford Zoo)] * [http://www.wingsonthewater.com/ Chicken Wing Festival] * Strawberry Festival * [http://tasteofsyracuse.com/ Taste of Syracuse] * [http://cayuganet.org/tomatofest/ Tomatofest] * Central New York Brewfest * Empire Brewfest
==Historical== * Canal Day
==Holiday related== * [[First Night]] * [[Juneteenth]] celebration [https://web.archive.org/web/20060818231134/http://www.syracuse-juneteenth.org/ Syracuse Juneteenth Web site] * [[Syracuse St. Patrick's Parade]] [http://www.syracusestpatricksparade.org/ Official Web site] * Autumn Equinox Festival [http://www.cnyppd.org/ CNY Pagan Pride Day Web site] * [[Thanksgiving Day]] Parade * [[Veterans Day]] Ceremony & Parade * The Great Zoo Boo
==Music== * [[Syracuse Jazz Festival]] * CNY Bluegrass Association Festival * Empire State Brewing and Music Festival * [http://syracuse.com/entertainment/jazzfest/ CNY JazzFest] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060701062712/http://www.jazzinthesquare.org/ Jazz in the Square] * [http://nysbluesfest.com/ New York State Blues Festival] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050831155529/http://www.partyintheplaza.com/ Party in the Plaza concert series] * [http://www.syracuseareamusic.com/ Syracuse Area Music Awards] * World in the Square
==Parades, processions, walks, and marches== * [http://www.cnypride.org/ CNY [[LGBT]] Pride Parade and Festival] * CNY [[Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]] Walk * [[Hiroshima]]/[[Nagasaki, Nagasaki|Nagasaki]] Procession * [[Syracuse St. Patrick's Parade]] [http://www.syracusestpatricksparade.org Official Web site]
==Performing arts== * Syracuse International Arts & Puppet Festival * Shakespeare-in-the-Park
==Races and competitions== * Human Dogsled Race * [http://mountaingoatrun.com/ [[YMCA]] annual Mountain Goat Run] * Parks Run 4 Mile Race: Onondaga Park in Syracuse's [[Strathmore, Syracuse|Strathmore]] Neighborhood * Syracuse Festival of Races [http://www.festivalofraces.com Syracuse Festival of Races] * Mountain Goat [http://www.mountaingoatrun.com] * Syrathon [http://www.syracuse.ny.us/parks/specialeventssyrathon.html] * Syracuse Half Marathon [http://www.syracusehalf.com/]
==Regional fairs and festivals== * [[Great New York State Fair]] (late August to Labor day) * Skaneateles Festival * Solvay Summer Festival * Armed Forces Day, held in conjunction with a Syracuse Chiefs Baseball game * Super DIRT Week
==Unsorted== * [http://www.lafayetteapplefest.org/ Apple Festival] * Balloon Fest * Harborfest * Lights on the Lake * Rose Day * [http://www.saltcitycomiccon.com Salt City Comic-Con] * [http://www.hbrcny.com/parade Parade of Homes] * [http://www.cnyartonparade.com Art on Parade] * [http://www.rightcoastcars.com/syracuse-nationals.php Syracuse Nationals] * [http://syracusewinterfest.com/ Syracuse Winterfest]

page.title: List of entertainment events at Bell MTS Place

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
[[Bell MTS Place]] in [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], [[Canada]] is one of the busiest venues in North America since its opening in 2004.{{cite news|last=Kirbyson |first=Geoff |url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/10-years-283020981.html |title=MTS Centre celebrates a decade as a successful downtown venue |newspaper=[[Winnipeg Free Press]] |date=2014-11-18 |accessdate=2017-03-19}} In 2008, its placed 19th busiest arena in the world and 11th in North America, with 385,427 tickets (not including sporting events){{cite news |title=MTS Centre 19th-Busiest Showbiz Venue in World|first=Cameron|last=MacLean|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/mts_centre_19th-busiest_showbiz_venue_in_world38266214.html|newspaper=[[Winnipeg Free Press]]|date=January 24, 2009|accessdate=August 18, 2009}} In 2009, it ranked as the 39th busiest arena in the world, and 26th busiest in North America.{{cite web|title=Pollstar Top 100 Worldwide Arena Venues 2009|url=http://www.sprintcenter.com/resources/pdfs/20093QYTDTicketSalesChartsTop100ArenaVenues.pdf|work=Pollstar|accessdate=April 9, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705002155/http://www.sprintcenter.com/resources/pdfs/20093QYTDTicketSalesChartsTop100ArenaVenues.pdf|archivedate=July 5, 2010|df=}} The following is a list of concerts and other non-sport entertainment events that have taken place at Bell MTS Place. ==2004 - 2010== {{Expand list|date=March 2017}} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" |- ! colspan=4| Entertainment events at Bell MTS Place |- ! style="width:100px;"| Dates ! style="width:150px;"| Artists ! style="width:200px;"| Events ! style="width:150px;"| Supporting acts |- style="background:#ddd;" ! colspan=4| 2004 |- | November 16 | [[Winnipeg Symphony Orchestra]]

{{Infobox song contest |name = Melodifestivalen |year = 2015 |size = 250px |final = 14 March 2015 |semi1 = 7 February 2015 |semi2 = 14 February 2015 |semi3 = 21 February 2015 |semi4 = 28 February 2015 |second = 7 March 2015 |presenters = [[Robin Paulsson]]
[[Sanna Nielsen]] |director = |venue = [[Friends Arena]]
[[Solna Municipality|Solna]], Sweden |winner = "[[Heroes (Måns Zelmerlöw song)|Heroes]]" by [[Måns Zelmerlöw]] |vote = |entries = 28: 7 in each heat; 12 in the final (2 from each heat, 4 from the Second Chance round) |opening = |interval = }} '''Melodifestivalen 2015''' was the [[Sweden|Swedish]] music competition that selected [[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest 2015|Sweden's 55th entry]] for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015]].{{cite web|url=http://esctoday.com/83858/sweden-svt-confirms-participation-eurovision-2015/|title=Eurovision Sweden: SVT confirms participation in Eurovision 2015|work=esctoday.com|accessdate=29 September 2014}} [[Måns Zelmerlöw]] won with the song "[[Heroes (Måns Zelmerlöw song)|Heroes]]". The hosts for the show were [[Sanna Nielsen]] (winner of [[Melodifestivalen 2014]]) and comedian [[Robin Paulsson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/det-har-ar-sanna-nielsen-och-robin-paulsson-programledare-for-melodifestivalen-2015|title=Sanna Nielsen och Robin Paulsson – programledare för Melodifestivalen 2015|work=svt.se|accessdate=29 September 2014|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dagensmedia.se/nyheter/tv/article3851336.ece|title=Sanna Nielsen och Robin Paulsson leder Melodifestivalen|work=Dagens Media|accessdate=29 September 2014|language=Swedish}} For the fourteenth consecutive year, the competition consisted of four semi-finals, a "Second Chance" round, and a final. However, the total number of competing entries was reduced from 32 to 28. The 28 competing entries were divided into four semi-finals, with seven compositions in each. From each semifinal, the songs that earned first and second place went directly to the final, while the songs that placed third and fourth proceeded to the Second Chance semi-final. The bottom three songs in each semifinal were eliminated from the competition.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=a_bigger_final_for_swedens_melodifestivalen|title=Sweden's Melodifestivalen dates, changes and presenters announced|date=29 September 2014|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150331164404/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=a_bigger_final_for_swedens_melodifestivalen|archivedate=31 March 2015|df=}} A new rule for the 2015 edition of the competition stipulated that at least 50% of the selected entries were to be written by female composers or lyricists in a full or partial capacity.{{cite web|title=Nu är det dags att skriva låtar till Melodifestivalen 2015|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/nu-ar-det-dags-att-skriva-latar-till-melodifestivalen-2015|publisher=Sveriges Television|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=24 June 2014|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Rekordmånga låtar tävlar i Svensktoppen nästa |url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=3147&artikel=5831725 |publisher=Sveriges Radio |accessdate=14 March 2015 |date=8 April 2014 |language=Swedish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513011518/http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=3147&artikel=5831725 |archivedate=13 May 2014 |df= }} == Format == Melodifestivalen 2015 was the fourteenth consecutive year in which the competition will take place in different cities across Sweden. The four semifinals were held in [[Gothenburg]] (7 February), [[Malmö]] (14 February), [[Östersund]] (21 February) and [[Örebro]] (28 February). The Second Chance round took place in [[Helsingborg]] on 7 March while the final in [[Solna Municipality|Solna]] was held on 14 March. === Schedule and ratings === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Show !! Date !! City !! Venue !! Viewers !! Melodifestivalen 2015|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/eric-saade-ar-i-final-i-melodifestivalen-2015|publisher=[[SVT]]|accessdate=7 February 2015|language=Swedish}} |- | Semi Final 2 || 14 [[Östersund]] || [[Östersund Arena]] || 3,145,000 || 2,865,979{{cite web|last1=Petersson|first1=Emma|title=Jon Henrik Fjällgren och Isa är i final i Melodifestivalen Second Chance == The Second Chance ''(Andra chansen)'' round was held on 7 March 2015 in [[Helsingborg Arena]], [[Helsingborg]]. Unlike in the previous editions, four out of eight competing entries were sent to the final this year. The preliminary two-phase voting introduced in 2013 was eliminated, bringing a duel-only competition back. The duels are as follows: It was announced that [[Malena Ernman]], Melodifestivalen [[Melodifestivalen 2009|winner]] and [[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest 2009|Sweden's representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009|2009 Eurovision Song Contest]] would join [[Behrang Miri]] and Victor Crone on stage to do the opera vocals.{{cite web|title=Sweden: Former winners return to Melodifestivalen for Andra chansen|url=http://escxtra.com/2015/03/04/former-winners-return-to-melodifestivalen-for-andra-chansen/|website=escxtra.com|publisher=escXtra.com|accessdate=4 March 2015}} {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! Victor Crone | align="left"| "[[Det rår vi inte för]]" ''(We can't help it)'' | 297,739 | align="left"| Out |- style="background:gold;font-weight:bold;" | 2 | align="left"| [[Samir & Viktor]] | align="left"| "[[Groupie (Samir & Viktor song)|Groupie]]" | 628,022 | align="left"| Final |} ==Final== The grand final of this year's Melodifestivalen was held on 14 March in the 28,000-seat [[Friends Arena]] in [[Solna Municipality|Solna]].{{cite web|title=Stockholm: All about the final of the Eurovision Song Contest 2015|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/tavlingen/2015/allt-om-finalen-i-melodifestivalen-2015-i-stockholm|publisher=[[SVT]]}} Unlike in the previous editions of Melodifestivalen, twelve songs competed in this year's final, two more than before. Eight finalists were selected during the four-week semi finals and four from the ''Second Chance'' round.{{cite web|title=Här är artisterna som är i final i Melodifestivalen 2015|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/har-ar-artisterna-som-ar-i-final-i-melodifestivalen-2015|website=svt.se/Melodifestivalen|publisher=[[SVT]]|language=Swedish}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Draw{{cite web|last1=Escudero|first1=Victor M.|title=Sweden: Melodifestivalen final line-up complete|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=sweden_melodifestivalen_final_line-up_complete|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=8 March 2015|date=7 March 2015}} !Artist !Song

{{Infobox play | name = My Redbreast | image = My Redbreast-2012.jpg | image_size = 225px | caption = Poster 'My Redbreast', 2012 | writer = [[Miho Mosulishvili]] | genre = [[Tragicomedy]] | setting = 21st-century Georgia | subject = Chito, Sopho, Shoka, Toko, Baxter O'Sullivan, Alice O'Sullivan | premiere = July 12, 2013 | place = Municipal Theatre of Bolnisi (Georgia) | orig_lang = Georgian }} '''''My Redbreast''''' (Sorrowfully, very sorrowfully comedy)<ref>{{Citation |url = http://openlibrary.org/books/OL25420225M/9_Plays_VS_Violence |publisher = ESPO |publication-date = 2012 |author = Group of authors |title = 9 Plays VS Violence }}</ref> is a 2012 play by [[Georgian people|Georgian]] [[playwright]] [[Miho Mosulishvili]].
==Plot synopsis== Sopho returns from America, where she had been for the last twelve years, for the death anniversary of her husband. She finds that her school friend, Shoka, is pregnant. Moreover, it turns out that her husband, Chito, had not died. He married Shoka and his tombstone in their yard was just a means of extorting money from Sopho.
The husband, friend and even her son (Toko) had to cheat Sopho to take money from her and pay for the interest for the apartment, which they had put in the bank.
They were alarmed by Sopho's unexpected arrival.
Sopho decides not to go to America, although her son Toko manages to bring to Georgia old Baxter, whom his mother was taking care in the States. He wants his mother to take care of him in Georgia, so as not to lose money.
Sopho refuses to look after Baxter and makes her family members care for him. Baxter, in this way "punishes" idlers - Chito, Shoka and Toko.
Baxter intends to propose to Sopho, but since she was supporting the idlers he concludes that she was like them.
In the final scene the persons are close to the Celestial Court. Their roles change - Sopho and Baxter care for Chito, Shoka and Toko who are confined to invalid chairs.
Baxter O'Sullivan names Sopho as "My redbreast" and from here occurs play heading.
==Characters== * '''Sopho''' — Chito's first wife, age 42 * '''Chito''' — The speculator, Valiko Chitorelidze, age 44 * '''Shoka''' — Chito's second wife, age 42 * '''Toko''' — Chito's son, age 27 * '''Baxter O'Sullivan''' — age 69 * '''Alice O'Sullivan''' — daughter of Baxter O'Sullivan, age 35
==Production== * July 12, 2013 — Municipal Theatre of Bolnisi (Georgia), Director Zurab Khvedelidze * June 5, 2014 — [[Marjanishvili Theater|Marjanishvili State Academic Drama Theatre]] (Georgia),<ref>[http://www.marjanishvili.ge/en/repertoire/small-stage?184 My Redbreast] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304101031/http://www.marjanishvili.ge/en/repertoire/small-stage?184 |date=2016-03-04 }}</ref> Director [[Khatuna Milorava]] * February 26, 2016 — Vaso Godziashvili Municipal Theatre of Velistsikhe (Georgia), Director Omar Kakabadze * May 17, 2016 — Khulo State Drama Theatre (Georgia), Director Gega Kurtsikidze
==Publication== * October 2, 2015 — Glosa Publishing, Tbilisi, Total Pages: 84. {{ISBN|9789941944628}}<ref>[https://openlibrary.org/books/OL25774806M/Chemo_Mezholia Chemo Mezholia]</ref> * December 15, 2016 - 'Mana Sarkanrīklīte (Skumja, ļoti skumja komēdija)', Vītola publishing, Latvia, Translated from Georgian into Latvian by Nino Jakobidze<ref>[http://www.dzirkstele.lv/kultura-un-izklaide/gulbene-izdod-gramatu-ar-gruzinu-dramaturga-mikho-mosulisvili-lugas-mana-sarkanriklite-tulkojumu-lat-152907#comments Gulbenē izdod grāmatu ar gruzīnu dramaturga Mikho Mosulišvili lugas “Mana Sarkanrīklīte” tulkojumu latviešu valodā] (in latvian)</ref>
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://openlibrary.org/works/OL16798567W/9_Plays_VS_Violence 9 Plays VS Violence]
{{Miho Mosulishvili}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:My Redbreast}} [[Category:2012 plays]] [[Category:Plays based on real people]] [[Category:Works by Miho Mosulishvili]]

{{Infobox ancient site | name = Myndus | native_name = Μύνδος | alternate_name = | image = Myndos.jpg | alt = | caption = Myndos' Rabbit Island in modern [[Gümüslük]] | map_type = Turkey | map_alt = | map_size = 285 | relief = | coordinates = {{coord|37|3|11|N|27|14|0|E|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Gümüslük]], [[Muğla Province]], [[Turkey]] | region = [[Caria]] | type = | part_of = | length = | width = | area = | height = | builder = | material = | built = | abandoned = | epochs = <!-- actually displays as "Periods" --> | cultures = | dependency_of = | occupants = | event = | excavations = | archaeologists = | condition = | ownership = | management = | public_access = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | notes = }}
'''Myndus''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|ɪ|n|d|ə|s}}) or '''Myndos''' ({{lang-el|{{lang|grc|Μύνδος}}}}) was an ancient [[Dorians|Dorian]] colony of [[Troezen]], on the coast of [[Caria]] in [[Asia Minor]], ([[Turkey]]), sited on the [[Bodrum]] Peninsula, a few miles northwest of [[Halicarnassus]]. The site is now occupied by the modern village of [[Gümüslük]].
==History== Myndos was protected by strong walls, and had a good harbor. ([[Pausanias (geographer)|Paus.]] ii. 30. § 8; [[Strabo]] xiv. p. 658; [[Arrian]], Anab. i. 20, ii. 5.) Otherwise, the place is not of much importance in ancient history. Both [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]] (v. 29) and [[Stephanus of Byzantium]] (''s. v.'') mention [[Palaemyndus]] as an ancient Carian settlement near to Myndus, which seems to have become deserted after Dorian Mynduse was founded. (Comp. Strab. xiii. p. 611). [[Mela]] (i. 16) and Pliny (''l. c.'') also speak of a place called ''Neapolis'' in the same peninsula and as no other authors mention such a place in that part of the country, it has been supposed that Myndus (the Dorian colony) and Neapolis were the same place. Pliny, however, mentions both Myndus and Neapolis as two different towns.
The [[Cynicism (philosophy)|cynic philosopher]] [[Diogenes of Sinope]] visited Myndos and noticed how large the city gates were, relative to the town; he cynically remarked; "Oh men of Myndos, I urge you to shut the city gates, as your town might exit from these!". Sections of the town walls and gate have been restored with financial assistance from private companies.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =MUĞLA Port Of Myndos| work =| publisher =pointsfromturkey.com| date =| url =http://www.pointsfromturkey.com/port_of_myndos.html| doi =| accessdate =26 Mar 2009| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20080605224817/http://www.pointsfromturkey.com/port_of_myndos.html| archivedate =2008-06-05| df =}}</ref>
Myndian ships are mentioned in the expedition of Anaxagoras against Naxos. (Herod. v. 33.) [[Herodotus]] relates the story of how a captain from Myndus, Scylax, was found to have left no guards on his ship while a Persian force was preparing to attack the island of [[Naxos (island)|Naxos]]. The Persian commander, [[Megabates]], flew into a rage and had him put in stocks, at which point [[Aristagoras]], a [[tyrant]] from [[Miletus]] helping several Naxian oligarchs to retake Naxos, discovered what had happened to his guest-friend Scylax. Pleading with Megabates to no avail for Scylax, he released him anyway, incurring the Persian commander's wrath. The consequence of this falling out was that, according to Herodotus, Megabates warned the Naxians of what was afoot, ruining the expedition and in turn Aristagoras who, with nowhere to go, stirred up the [[Ionian Revolt]]. This is a classic example of Ionian αταξιη (lack of discipline, disorder, licentiousness), a charge commonly levelled at them, especially in the 5th century by [[Athens]].
At a later time, when [[Alexander the Great]] besieged Halicarnassus, he was anxious first to make himself master of Myndus; but when he attempted to take it by surprise, the Myndians, with the aid of reinforcements from Halicarnassus repulsed him with some loss. (Arrian, ''l. c.''; comp. Hecat. Fragm. 229; Polyb. xvi. 15, 21; Scylax, p. 38; Ptol. v. 2. § 9; Liv. xxxvii. 15; Hierocl. p. 687.) [[Athenaeus]] (i. 32) states that the wine grown in the district of Myndus was good for digestion.
Remains of the city are visible in and around Gümüslük and in the adjacent waters; it is supposed that some unrecorded earthquake caused seafront sections of the ancient town to be submerged.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Gümüslük | work = | publisher = Bodrumpages.com | date = 2000–2004 | url = http://www.bodrumpages.com/English/textgumusluk.html | doi = | accessdate = 26 Mar 2009 }}</ref> As a result, much of the land and offshore areas are protected from interference and development.
==Ecclesiastical history==
Myndus was an [[episcopal see]] of [[Caria]], a suffragan of [[Stauropolis]] (Aphrodisias). The ''[[Notitiæ episcopatuum]]'' allude to it as late as the 12th or 13th century. However, only four of its bishops are known: Archelaus, who attended the [[First Council of Ephesus]] (431); Alphius, who assisted at the [[Council of Chalcedon]] (451); John who was present at the [[Third Council of Constantinople]] (680); and another John who went to the [[Second Council of Nicaea]] (787).<ref>Sophrone Pétridès, "Myndus" ''The Catholic Encyclopedia'', 1911. [http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/10660c.htm full text]</ref>
The bishopric is included in the [[Catholic Church]]'s list of [[titular see]]s.<ref>''Annuario Pontificio 2013'' (Libreria Editrice Vaticana, 2013, {{ISBN|978-88-209-9070-1}}), p. 931</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.4)
revision.text:
The '''Northampton Balloon Festival''' is an annual [[hot air balloon festival]] held in [[Northampton]], England.
The original festival was held in [[The Racecourse, Northampton|The Racecourse]] and managed by the Borough Council, and took place over a Friday, Saturday and Sunday in mid-August. The main features of the festival were the twice-daily [[hot air balloon]] lifts and a balloon glow, but other attractions included trade stalls, live music and arena entertainment.
==History== The first festival was held in 1990. The start attractions were the Chubb fire extinguisher and the Rupert The Bear balloons. In its early years The Northampton balloon was a soaring success with families encouraged to come and enjoy the weekend, looking at balloons and visiting various trade stalls across the park.
In 2001 the festival was joined with the [[Northampton Town Show]] (previously held during July) to become the ''Northampton Festival'', but has since reverted to its original name. Sadly the early years of the new millennium coincided with the rise of the "chav" and a growing obsession behind making money the festival became an oversized fairground full of topless louts. This was clearly the beginning of the end for what had become one of the town´s prized attractions.
The 2004 festival featured the ''[[Sugababes]]'', ''[[Big Brovaz]]'', and [[Ronan Keating]].
The 2005 festival featured [[Rachel Stevens]] and [[Lemar]].
The 2007 festival was a disaster due to poor attendance caused by bad weather on the last two days and the fact that the council decided to charge adults for admission, which discouraged many adults without young children from attending and spending money at the stalls.
The 2008 festival was scaled down from before, with fewer stalls, and featured [[Rick Astley]] and [[Signature (dance group)|Signature]] but neither were able to revive the festival's fortunes and the event made a huge loss.
The Borough Council ceased its funding and in mid-2009 the festival was revived by new organisers and moved to [[Billing Aquadrome]]. It took place 14–16 August 2009 at the new location with free admission.<ref>[http://www.northamptonballoonfestival.net/ New Balloon Festival website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020045643/http://www.northamptonballoonfestival.net/ |date=20 October 2007 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.northamptonchron.co.uk/news/Billing-Aquadrome-39best-site-for.5327696.jp Chronicle & Echo]</ref>
The 2010 Northampton Balloon Festival was once again based at Billing Aquadrome, however that year the organisers chose to charge entry.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} The Balloon Festival sat alongside an existing event, the American Car Show and included a variety of stalls and fairground rides.
In 2012, it was announced that Pure Leisure, the owners of Billing Aquadrome had agreed sponsorship of the event, for a further 3 years.
The Balloon Festival was held on Friday 15 to Sunday 17 August 2014, 14-16 August 2015 and between 19-21 August 2016.
==See also== * [[Hot air balloon festival]]s
==External links== *[http://www.thenorthamptonballoonfestival.co.uk/ The Official Website of The Northampton Balloon Festival] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040404052442/http://www.bbc.co.uk/northamptonshire/festival/ BBC guide to the Balloon Festival] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071020045643/http://www.northamptonballoonfestival.net/ Northampton Balloon Festival Website - Picture gallery of past festivals]
