==Bands== {{Main article|Rose Parade marching bands}} [[File:Bandtournamentrosesparade.jpg|thumb|left|[[Londonderry High School]] Marching Lancer Band, from New Hampshire during the 2004 parade]] Top marching bands from all over the world are invited. Many of the nation's top high school marching bands, along with college and organizational marching bands participate.
The bands participating in the parade have developed traditions throughout the its history. For example, [[Pasadena City College]]'s Tournament of Roses Honor Band always marches in the Rose Parade, along with the [[Los Angeles Unified School District]] All City Honor Band, all of whom are selected by audition the previous autumn. Positions in both bands are coveted, and those selected are among the best student musicians in California.
The Tournament of Roses Honor Band's Herald Trumpets unit marches and plays directly before the Rose Queen's float. Nine trumpet players and one snare drummer are selected from those who audition for the band for the unit.
University marching bands from the two schools competing in the Rose Bowl Game are invited to march in the parade. They typically accompany the float that represents the school and conference.
Bands that have a long-standing arrangement to be in the parade include:<ref>[http://www.tournamentofroses.com/roseparade/participants.asp Rose Parade Participants] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014175306/http://www.tournamentofroses.com/roseparade/participants.asp |date=2008-10-14 }}</ref> * The official [[Tournament of Roses Honor Band]] hosted by [[Pasadena City College]] consisting of members of the college's Lancer Marching Band and talented high school musicians from throughout California (89th Rose Parade appearance in 2018).<ref>[http://blog.tournamentofroses.com/2013/05/23/annual-bands-part-1/ Annual bands – Part 1], ''Tournament Times'', May 23, 2013</ref> * The [[Los Angeles Unified School District#All District High School Honor Band|Los Angeles Unified School District]] All City Honor Band * The [[Salvation Army]] Tournament of Roses Marching Band consisting of local and visiting Salvation Army musicians (97th appearance in 2016) * The [[United States Marine Corps]] West Coast Composite Band
In 1891, the [[Monrovia, California|Monrovia]] Town Band was the first musical group to perform in the Rose Parade. In 1998, the [[Washington Township High School (New Jersey)|Washington Township High School]] Minutemen Marching Band from [[Sewell, New Jersey]] became the first band in the history of the Rose Parade to decorate its entire ranks with live flowers, in keeping with the practice of decorating the parade floats. From the neighboring town of Arcadia, the Arcadia High School Apache Marching Band and Colorgaurd has appeared for 15 years, returning about every four years. The Allen Eagle Escadrille from Allen, Texas had a record breaking 780 members in the 2016 Rose Parade.
In addition to the parade, the bands participate in a two-day, three-show Bandfest at [[Pasadena City College]]'s [[Jackie Robinson|Jackie]] and [[Mack Robinson (athlete)|Mack]] Robinson Stadium, usually on December 29 and 30 (December 30 and 31 when the parade is on January 2). Twenty bands participated in the 2016 parade.
==Rose Parade Theme== [[File:Tournament of Roses Parade 2010 Float.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Theme float "2010: A Cut Above the Rest" rolling down Colorado Boulevard during the parade]] {{Main article|Tournament of Roses Parade themes}}
Shortly after the parade in January, the newly elected President of the Tournament of Roses has the duty of picking a theme for the forthcoming festivities. Most of the floral floats in the parade are inspired by this theme.
On January 18, 2018, Gerald Freeny was confirmed as President of the [[Pasadena Tournament of Roses|Pasadena Tournament of Roses Association]]. He announced that the theme for the 130th Rose Parade and 105th Rose Bowl Game is ''The Melody of Life''. The parade and bowl game will be held on January 1, 2019. The Tournament of Roses President will lead the 14-member Executive Committee and the organization of 935 volunteer members for the upcoming year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Henry|first1=Jason|title=Tournament of Roses president unveils 2018 Rose Parade theme|url=http://www.pasadenastarnews.com/lifestyle/20170119/tournament-of-roses-president-unveils-2018-rose-parade-theme|accessdate=20 January 2017|publisher=[[Pasadena Star News]]|date=19 January 2017}}</ref>
==Grand Marshal== {{Main article|Grand Marshals of the Rose Parade}} [[File:Louis Zamperini at announcement of 2015 Tournament of Roses Grand Marshal.JPG|thumb|2015 Grand Marshal [[Louis Zamperini]] at Tournament House]] The Grand Marshal of the parade is an honorary position selected by the president of the Tournament. Many are picked for a relationship to the theme that is also picked by the president.
The 2018 Grand Marshal was [[Academy Awards]] nominee and distinguished humanitarian [[Gary Sinise]]. For the 2017 parade, [[Greg Louganis]], [[Janet Evans]] and [[Allyson Felix]] served as marshals. Documentary filmmaker [[Ken Burns]] was selected as the 2016 Grand Marshal.
The 2015 parade Grand Marshal was to be [[Louis Zamperini]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Lloyd|first=Jonathan|title=War Hero, Former Olympian Louis Zamperini Named Rose Parade Grand Marshal|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Rose-Parade-Grand-Marshal-258614401.html?_osource=SocialFlowFB_LABrand|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|accessdate=May 9, 2014|date=May 9, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=BBC|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-28149957|date= 3 July 2014|title= Olympic runner and WW2 prisoner Louis Zamperini dies}}</ref> After his death on July 2, 2014, the Tournament announced that it was "committed to honoring him as the Grand Marshal of the 2015 Rose Parade."<ref>[http://tournamentofroses.com/News/NewsDetail/tabid/132/article/201849/THE-TOURNAMENT-OF-ROSES-EXPRESSES-OUR-HEARTFELT-SYMPATHY-TO-THE-FAMILY-OF-LOUIS-ZAMPERINI.aspx The Tournament of Roses Expresses Our Heartfelt Sympathy to The Family of Louis Zamperini], Pasadena Tournament of Roses Association, July 3, 2014</ref> During the parade, USC mascot [[Traveler (mascot)|Traveler]] walked in his place, riderless to honor Zamperini.<ref>http://news.usc.edu/72869/riderless-horse-traveler-to-honor-louis-zamperini-at-rose-parade/</ref>
[[Vin Scully]] was chosen as the Grand Marshal of the 2014 parade and Rose Bowl Game. Previously, President Sally Bixby named [[Jane Goodall]] as the Grand Marshal for the 2013 parade, succeeding [[J. R. Martinez]], the 2012 grand marshal.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Corrigan|first1=Kelly|title=Jane Goodall named 2013 Rose Parade grand marshal|url=http://articles.lacanadaonline.com/2012-04-25/news/tn-vsl--0426-jane-goodall-named-2013-rose-parade-grand-marshal_1_grand-marshal-chimpanzee-greeting-tanzania-s-gombe-national-park|accessdate=12 February 2015|work=La Canada Valley Sun|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=25 April 2012}}</ref>
[[Food Network]] star [[Paula Deen]] was the [[Grand Marshal]] of the 2011 parade.<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=11975149 Chef Paula Deen Named Rose Parade Grand Marshal], ''AP'' via ''ABC News'', October 26, 2010</ref> Captain [[Chesley Sullenberger]] was the 2010 Grand Marshal and actress [[Cloris Leachman]] served as the 2009 Grand Marshal, the 10th female grand marshal in the history of the parade. [[Mary Pickford]] was the first female Grand Marshal. Other Hollywood celebrities who appeared as Grand Marshal are [[Leo Carrillo]], [[Harold Lloyd]], [[Walt Disney]], [[John Wayne]], and [[Bob Hope]].
'''Repeat Marshals of the Tournament of Roses Parade''' * [[Shirley Temple]] (1928–2014), 1939, 1989, 1999 * Charles Daggett, 1900, 1901, 1914 * [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] (1890–1969), 1951, 1964 (note that Cpl. Robert S. Gray filled in for him in 1951) * [[Bob Hope]] (1903–2003), 1947, 1969 * [[Richard Nixon]] (1913–1994), 1953, 1960 * C. C. Reynolds, 1902, 1903 * Dr. Francis F. Rowland, 1890, 1892, 1894, 1904, 1905, 1910, 1916 * Dr. Ralph Skillen, 1907, 1908, 1911 * Edwin Stearns, 1896, 1897 * Martin H. Weight, 1898, 1899 * [[Earl Warren]] (1891–1974), 1943, 1955
==Rose Queen and Royal Court== {{Main article|Queens of the Rose Parade}}
Each September, some 1,000 young women (and a few young men) between the ages of 17 to 21, interview for the honor of serving as a member of the Tournament of Roses Royal Court<sup>[[Queens of the Tournament of Roses|[1]]]</sup>. The [[Pasadena Tournament of Roses]] administers a selection process to determine which greater Pasadena-area young women will have the honor of being crowned '''Queen of the [[Tournament of Roses Parade|Tournament of Roses]]''', or more commonly known as "[[Queens of the Tournament of Roses|Rose Queen]]." In addition to one Rose Queen, six Rose Princesses will also be selected to make up the Royal Court. The Royal Court will then ride on a specially-designed [[Float (parade)|float]] in the Rose Parade and will also preside over the [[Rose Bowl Game]]. The Royal Court will also attend over one hundred events in the [[Southern California]] area as ambassadors of the Tournament of Roses.
''[[One Tree Hill (TV series)|One Tree Hill]]'' and ''[[Chicago P.D.]]'' actress [[Sophia Bush]] was Rose Queen in 2000. 1997 Rose Princess Lisa Remillard is an anchor with [[San Diego]]'s [[KUSI]] television station.<ref>[http://www.kusi.com/story/25183271/lisa-remillard Lisa Remillard] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011185227/http://www.kusi.com/story/25183271/lisa-remillard |date=2014-10-11 }}, KUSI, March 2014</ref>
The 2015 Rose Queen is Madison Triplett (John Marshall Fundamental High School). Members of the Royal Court are Mackenzie Byers (Pasadena City College), Gabrielle Current (Flintridge Sacred Heart Academy), Veronica Mejia (Pasadena City College), Bergen Onufer (Mayfield Senior School), Simona Shao (Westridge School) and Emily Stoker (Temple City High School).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-rose-queen-named-20141022-story.html|title=Madison Triplett crowned as 2015 Rose Queen|last=Times|first=Los Angeles|website=latimes.com|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref>
The 2016 Rose Queen is Erika Karen Winter (Flintridge Preparatory School). Members of the Royal Court are Natalie Breanne Hernandez-Barber (Alverno High School), Donaly Elizabeth Marquez (Blair International Baccalaureate School), Bryce Marie Bakewell (Flintridge Sacred Heart Academy), Rachelle Liu (San Marino High School), Regina Pullens (Maranatha High School), and Sarah Shaklan (La Canada High School).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/socal/la-canada-valley-sun/community/tsn-vsl-flintridge-prep-student-erika-winter-named-98th-rose-queen-20151023-story.html|title=Flintridge Prep student Erika Winter crowned 98th Rose Queen|last=Cañada|first=La|website=La Cañada Valley Sun|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref>
The 2017 Rose Queen is Victoria "Tori" Castellanos (Temple City High School).
Isabella Marez of La Salle High School was crowned as the 100th Tournament of Roses Queen on October 18, 2017. Other members of the 2018 Royal Court: Julianne Lauenstein (La Cañada High School); Syndey Pickering (Arcadia High School); Savannah Bradley (Pasadena High School); Georgia Cervenka (La Cañada High School); Lauren Buehner (Arcadia High School); Alexandra Artura (Flintridge Sacred Heart Academy).
==Attendance==
More recent attendance figures are followed by the TV and predicted attendance in parentheses. Most estimates are conducted by the Tournament of Roses and the [[Pasadena Police Department (California)|Pasadena Police Department]]. A number of studies were conducted by the [[UCLA Anderson School of Management|Anderson School of Management]] at [[UCLA]] on attendance and economic impact to Southern California. The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' ran a study in 1980 that said the actual attendance at the parade was actually about 60% of what is claimed each year.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} * 1890 – 2,000 * 2002 – 800,000 (1,000,000; drop blamed on [[September 11, 2001 attacks|9/11]].) * 2004 – 1,000,000 * 2009 – 700,000 (Pasadena had 1,000,000 visitors during the week of the parade.) * 2011 – 700,000 * 2012 – 700,000 (with an estimated 70 million watching via worldwide television). * 2013 – 700,000
==Broadcast== The Rose Parade is televised on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[NBC]], [[Univision]] (in Spanish), [[HGTV]], [[Sky Link TV]] (in Mandarin and Cantonese), [[Hallmark Channel]], [[RFD TV]], and [[KTLA]] (the latter three offer interruption-free coverage, although KTLA continues to repeat the parade throughout the day with commercials). [[WGN-TV]] in Chicago carried KTLA's uninterrupted coverage of the 2009 parade (WGN and KTLA are both owned by [[Tribune Broadcasting]], subsidiary of the [[Tribune Media Company]]).<ref>[http://www.wgntv.com/holiday_specials WGN TV Chicago: Holiday specials]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Accessed 2008-12-30.</ref> Until 2005, the parade was also broadcast on [[CBS]], and [[KTTV]] also televised the parade from the station's sign-on in 1949 until 1995. ABC serves as the official broadcaster of the parade, and its sister network [[ESPN]] currently airs the Rose Bowl (which formerly aired on ABC). * The 1947 parade was the first to be televised (on KTLA). However, reportedly experimental station W6XAO (now [[KCBS-TV]]) broadcast the 1940 parade. * The 1954 parade was also the first program televised in the [[NTSC]] [[color television]] format nationwide on [[NBC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://novia.net/~ereitan/rose_parade.html|title=Colorcast of the Rose Parade|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990429045929/http://www.novia.net/~ereitan/rose_parade.html|archivedate=1999-04-29|df=}}</ref> * The 2004 parade was first time aired in Chinese Mandarin language on Chinese TV station: [[Sky Link TV]]. * The 2009 Parade was broadcast to 217 countries (79 countries live) in over 20 languages. * The Tournament of Roses website had approximately 13 million hits during the week of the 2009 parade. * The website was viewed in 150 countries. * The 2010 Parade was watched via TV in 127 countries including China. * The 2011 Parade had a total television reach of approximately 47 million television viewers in the U.S. and was seen by approximately 28 million viewers internationally. * The 2013 Parade was also streamed on [[Xbox Live]] via both their [[WatchESPN]] (U.S.) and [[Xbox Live Event Player|Live Event Player]] (all other countries) applications. * The 2018 Parade was streamed on [[Amazon Video]], with fictional hosts Cord Hosenbeck ([[Will Ferrell]]) and Tish Cattigan ([[Molly Shannon]]) providing satirical commentary.
==Volunteers==
===Leadership=== {{Main article|List of Presidents of the Tournament of Roses Association|l1=Presidents of the Tournament of Roses Association}} Each year, the newly elected Tournament of Roses President is responsible for selecting the year's theme and grand marshal. Preparation and construction of the floral floats theoretically begins after the theme is announced. The selection of marching bands is already well under way except for Rose Bowl Game college bands. In 2005, Libby Evans Wright was elected as the first female president of the Association.
The Pasadena Tournament of Roses appointed former ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' executive P. Scott McKibben as its executive director in 2010, replacing John M. (Mitch) Dorger, who had served as CEO since 2000. On September 8, 2011, he resigned for personal reasons. Chief Operating Officer William B. Flinn was named interim executive director.<ref>[http://www.pasadenastarnews.com/news/ci_18852302 McKibben resigns from Tournament of Roses top job] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108034309/http://www.pasadenastarnews.com/news/ci_18852302 |date=2012-01-08 }}, ''Pasadena Star-News'', September 8, 2011</ref> From March 1, 2012 to January 2, 2017, William B. Flinn took over the role of Executive Director. David Eads became the Executive Director in 2017.
===Operations and the parade=== [[File:TOR volunteers prepping flowers.jpg|thumb|left|Volunteers]] The Tournament of Roses has become such a large event that it requires 65,000 hours of combined [[Human resources|manpower]] each year, or the equivalent of roughly 7.42 years of combined manpower. Fortunately for the Association, the group has 935 members, each of whom is assigned to one of 34 committees, and around 50 student ambassadors. Responsibilities include: * Selecting Parade participants * Inspecting and testing floats for safe and reliable operation * Assembling the parade elements * Conducting the parade through the streets of Pasadena * Directing visitors on New Year's Day * Assisting the public and the media in viewing the parade * Giving presentations about the Tournament to community groups * Supervising elements of the Rose Bowl Game (and also the BCS National Championship Game when held in Pasadena)
During the Parade, many Tournament members are required to wear white suits with red ties, name tags, membership pins and official ribbons. Because of this, the volunteers are commonly referred to as "White Suiters."<ref>[http://www.tournamentofroses.com/PasadenaTournamentofRoses/AboutUs/PasadenaTournamentOfRoses.aspx About Us] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121122114224/http://www.tournamentofroses.com/PasadenaTournamentofRoses/AboutUs/PasadenaTournamentOfRoses.aspx |date=2012-11-22 }}, Pasadena Tournament of Roses, Retrieved November 2012</ref> In December each year, a fleet of white vehicles with special "ToR" [[license plates]] are seen throughout the [[San Gabriel Valley]]. The use of these cars is currently donated by American Honda for use by high-ranking Tournament members. [[File:Tournament of Roses Parade scouts.jpg|left|[[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scouts]] carrying banner|thumb|200px]]
Each year, an honor troop of [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scouts]] from the [[San Gabriel Valley Council]], (now [[Greater Los Angeles Area Council|GLAAC]]), and "The Tournament Troop" of Girl Scout [[Gold Award (Girl Scouts of the USA)|Gold Award recipients]] of the [[Arcadia]] Service Unit of the Girl Scouts Greater Los Angeles, is selected to carry the parade banners down the route. Each year, for the last 35 years, more than 100 scouts have participated.
The ''Tournament of Roses Radio Amateurs'' (TORRA) provided audio communications and video co-ordination for the parade officials through the use of [[Amateur radio]] from 1968 until 2005. With over 300 [[Amateur radio operator|ham radio operators]] in TORRA there were several [[Amateur radio station|ham radio sites]] along the parade route equipped with [[amateur television]] as well as 2-way ham radios. Several mobile units – including motorcycles and pedestrian units (creepie-peepies) provided the video coverage. With modern technology and cell phone service, TORRA was no longer needed.
Thousands more volunteers help cover the floats in those beautiful flower and seed mixes during "Deco week," Dec 26- parade day. Many of these come back year after year, some even camp nearby to help all week long.
==Weather== [[File:PreRoseParade-010104.jpg|thumb|right|Spectators gather before the 2004 Rose Parade: some pay for seats in stands; others spend the night to "reserve" a free spot on the sidewalks.]]
For the 2006 Tournament of Roses Parade on January 2 (it is always held on January 2 when January 1 falls on a Sunday) winds with gusts up to {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and five [[inch]]es (130 [[millimeter|mm]]) of rain in the Pasadena area were predicted. The forecast proved accurate, ruining the 51 year record of good weather for the parade. It rained continuously and heavily throughout the entire 2006 parade. The President of the Tournament, the Grand Marshal of the Parade and the executive committee{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}}, deliberated into the early morning at the Tournament House. With street rumors circulating of the parade being canceled or postponed and restlessness of the crowd further east along the parade route, the parade got underway despite the bleak weather.<ref>{{cite web|title=117th Rose Parade|url=http://www.upi.com/enl-win/00cb734c6d2b6349c8af55d4caa43df8/|publisher=UPI|accessdate=31 December 2010}}</ref> Low television ratings and poor attendance plagued the ceremony. Some floats sustained water damage by the end of the parade.
==Related events== * Royal Court Interviews * Royal Ball * [[Queens of the Tournament of Roses|Rose Queen]] Announcement and Coronation Ceremony * [[College Football Playoff|Selection Sunday]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.collegefootballplayoff.com/selection-day|title=College Football Playoff|last=SportsLabs|website=www.collegefootballplayoff.com|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref> * [[Lawry's]] Beef Bowl * Decorating Places (for float viewing), various "barns" * Equestfest, Los Angeles Equestrian Center * Bandfest, [[Pasadena City College]] * Teams Day, [[Disneyland Resort]] * Rose Bowl Hall of Fame Ceremony, Rose Bowl * Rose Bowl Game Public Tailgate * [[Rose Bowl Game]] * Post Parade (for float viewing), Washington and Sierra Madre Boulevards
==Notes== * The animated 2007 movie "The Bee Movie" featured the Tournament of Roses * January 2, 1922 – First parade not held on New Year's Day (The parade is traditionally never held on a Sunday because when it was first started the Tournament did not want the horses to get spooked by the church bells<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tournamentofroses.com/rose-parade|title={{!}} Tournament of Roses|date=2014-12-07|website=Tournament of Roses|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref>) * January 3, 2002 – Tournament of Roses hosted the first [[BCS National Championship]] where [[2001 Miami Hurricanes football team|Miami]] defeated [[2001 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]], 37-14, and the Parade and the [[Rose Bowl Game]] were held on separate days * January 1, 2014 – The first same-sex marriage at the parade was held, for Aubrey Loots and Danny LeClair.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://nation.time.com/2014/01/02/first-gay-couple-weds-at-the-rose-parade/ | work=Time | date=January 2, 2014 |title=Rose Parade Sees First Gay Wedding}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Tournament of Roses Parade|Rose Parade}} {{Attached KML|display=inline,title}} * [http://www.tournamentofroses.com/ Tournament of Roses Parade official site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091027043028/http://www.tournamentofroses.com/therosediaries/ The Rose Diaries] * {{emmytvlegends title|tournament-of-roses-parade|Tournament of Roses Parade}} * [http://citytravelhub.com/rose-parade-2017-tournament-of-roses-pasadena-california-usa/ Rose Parade 2017, Pasadena, California]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Use British English|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox Theatre | name = Royal Lyceum Theatre | image = Royal Lyceum Theatre.jpg | caption = | address = 30B Grindlay Street | city = [[Edinburgh]] | county = [[Lothian]] | country = [[Scotland]] | designation = [[Listed building#Scotland|Category A Listed building]] | coordinates = {{coord|55.94674|-3.20440|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | architect = [[Charles J. Phipps|C. J. Phipps]] | owner = [[City of Edinburgh Council]] | tenant = Royal Lyceum Theatre Company | capacity = 658 | type = | opened = 10 September 1883 | website = {{URL|www.lyceum.org.uk}} }}
The '''Royal Lyceum Theatre''' is a 658-seat [[theatre]] in the city of [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]], named after the [[Theatre Royal Lyceum and English Opera House]], the residence at the time of legendary [[Shakespearean]] actor [[Henry Irving]]. It was built in 1883 by [[architect]] [[Charles J. Phipps|C. J. Phipps]] at a cost of £17,000 on behalf of James B. Howard and Fred. W. P. Wyndham,<ref name="oxford">{{Citation | last = Hartnoll | first = Phyllis | last2 = Found | first2 = Peter | title = The Concise Oxford Companion to the Theatre | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 1996 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1O79-RoyalLyceumTheatre.html | isbn = 978-0-19-211576-8 }}</ref> two theatrical managers and performers whose partnership became the renowned [[Howard & Wyndham Ltd]] created in 1895 by Michael Simons of Glasgow.<ref name="100yrs">{{Citation | last = Campbell | first = Donald | title = A brighter sunshine: A hundred years of the Edinburgh Royal Lyceum Theatre | publisher = Polygon | year = 1983 | url = | isbn = 978-0-904919-70-7 }}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Edinburgh/Lyceum.htm | title=The Royal Lyceum Theatre, Grindley Street and Cornwall Street, Edinburgh, Scotland}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Glasgow/TRHope.htm | title=The Theatre Royal, 282 Hope Street, Cowcaddens, Glasgow}}</ref> <ref>''The Theatre Royal: Entertaining a Nation'' by Graeme Smith, published 2008</ref>
With only four minor refurbishments, in 1929, 1977, 1991, and 1996, the Royal Lyceum remains one of the most original and unaltered of the architect's works.<ref name="building">[http://www.lyceum.org.uk/webpages/inside_history.php "Building history"], Royal Lyceum website</ref>
Opening night was 10th September 1883<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Opening of the Royal Lyceum Theatre|last=|first=|date=11 September 1883|work=The Edinburgh Evening News|access-date=10 September 2018|publisher=|via=http://britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk}}</ref> with a performance of ''[[Much Ado About Nothing]]'' by the company of the London Lyceum Theatre and starring Henry Irving and [[Ellen Terry]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Opening of the Lyceum Theatre|last=|first=|date=11 September 1883|work=The Scotsman|access-date=10 September 2018|via=http://britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk}}</ref>
In 1965, the building was purchased by the Edinburgh Corporation to house the newly formed '''Royal Lyceum Theatre Company''', who are now the permanent residents, leasing it from the [[City of Edinburgh Council|local council]].<ref name="company">[http://www.lyceum.org.uk/webpages/inside_history.php "Company history"], Royal Lyceum website</ref>
The Royal Lyceum has been one of the principal venues for the [[Edinburgh International Festival]] since the festival's inception in 1947, its owners renting out the building for three weeks every August for visiting companies, and often for a further week to [[Edinburgh Fringe|Fringe]] companies.<ref name="company"/>
The Royal Lyceum has primarily been known for its provision of drama. However it has also presented some significant opera, from the first tours of [[Carl Rosa Opera Company|Carl Rosa]] in the latter part of the 19th century through to the early decades of [[Scottish Opera]] in the 1960s and 1970s. Some important operas received their first Scottish performance at the Lyceum, including ''[[Madam Butterfly]]'', ''[[Manon]]'' and ''[[Die Meistersinger]]''.<ref>[http://www.operascotland.org/venue/77/Royal+Lyceum+Theatre+%7C+Edinburgh Fraser, Iain and Fraser, Stephen (2013) 'Royal Lyceum Theatre' OperaScotland]</ref>
The theatre was the first in Britain to be fitted with an iron safety curtain, and the first in Scotland to use electricity for house lighting.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Scotlandʼs splendid theatres : architecture and social history from the Reformation to the present day|last=Bruce.|first=Peter|date=1999|publisher=Polygon|isbn=978-0748662616|location=Edinburgh|pages=32–33|oclc=44184624}}</ref>
[[David Greig (dramatist)|David Greig]] took over from Mark Thomson as Artistic Director in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=David Greig named Lyceum Theatre’s artistic director| url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/culture/theatre/david-greig-named-lyceum-theatre-s-artistic-director-1-3882512 | location=Edinburgh | work=The Scotsman | date=9 September 2015}}</ref>
==Ghosts== [[File:Held by the enemy 03 - Weir Collection.jpg|thumb|300px|Poster for a performance of [[William Gillette|William Gillette's]] ''Held by the enemy'' at the theatre in 1887]] The theatre is believed to be haunted and there have been sightings of a blue lady who is believed to be [[Ellen Terry]], the actress who performed at the Lyceum’s first show. In addition a shadowy figure has been reportedly seen high above the stage in the lighting rig.<ref>{{cite news|title=Why you've more than a ghost of a chance of seeing a spook| url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/why-you-ve-more-than-a-ghost-of-a-chance-of-seeing-a-spook-1-1045900 | location=Edinburgh | work=The Scotsman | date=8 November 2004}}</ref> Many sightings have been reported to have been accompanied by a ringing noise.
==See also== *Adjoining buildings ** [[Traverse Theatre]] ** [[Usher Hall]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://lyceum.org.uk/ Official website] * [http://arthurlloyd.co.uk/Edinburgh/Lyceum.htm Royal Lyceum Theatre on Arthur Lloyd website] * A digitised collection of 63 [http://digital.nls.uk/74601946 Royal Lyceum theatre posters] from 1870-1900 at [[National Library of Scotland]] * [http://www.laughingaudience.co.uk/royal_lyceum_theatre_edinburgh.html] Academic, refereed papers on the Royal Lyceum Theatre Company 1965 to 2000, by Paul Iles
{{Scottish Theatres}}

Phipps buildings]] [[Category:Reportedly haunted locations in Edinburgh]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1883]] [[Category:Producing theatres in Scotland]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2012}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=HMT Acacia IWM FL 46.jpg |Ship caption=HMT ''Acacia'', sister ship to ''Walnut'' }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=United Kingdom |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|UK|naval}} |Ship name=HMT ''Walnut'' |Ship ordered= |Ship yard number=755 |Ship way number= |Ship laid down=15 June 1939 |Ship launched=12 August 1939 |Ship builder=[[Smiths Dock Company]], [[South Bank, Middlesbrough]], England |Ship completed=31 December 1939 |Ship christened= |Ship acquired= |Ship maiden voyage= |Ship out of service= |Ship registry= |Ship identification=[[Pennant number]] T103 |Ship fate=Sold to Stem Olson Company Limited 1948 |Ship status= |Ship notes=Source: [http://www.miramarshipindex.org.nz/ship/show?nameid=180002&shipid=75917 Miramar Ship Information Database, Record No. 5185985] }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header=title |Ship country= |Ship flag= |Ship name=SS ''Walnut'' |Ship registry={{flagicon|Sweden|civil}} [[Gothenburg]], Sweden |Ship acquired=1948 |Ship owner=Stem Olson Company Limited |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours= |Ship fate=Sold to Compania Maritima Walnut S/A in 1948 |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header=title |Ship country= |Ship flag= |Ship name=SS ''Walnut'' |Ship registry={{flagicon|Panama|civil}} [[Panama City]], Panama |Ship acquired=1948 |Ship owner=Compania Maritima Walnut S/A |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours= |Ship fate=Court Auction in 1949, Salvaged, Sold to Borromee Verreault Company 1951 |Ship status= |Ship notes=Source:[http://www.walnutship1948.ca/Walnut_ship_Estonian_Refugees_statistics.htm "Ship Statistics", ''SS Walnut 1948 - Voyaged to Freedom''] }}
{{Infobox ship career |Hide header=title |Ship country= |Ship flag= |Ship name=''Keta'' |Ship owner=Borromee Verreault Company |Ship namesake= |Ship acquired= |Ship in service= |Ship registry={{flagicon|Canada|civil}} [[City of Halifax|Halifax, Nova Scotia]] |Ship out of service= |Ship fate=Broken up [[Les Méchins, Quebec]], December 1976 by Nittolo Metal Company |Ship status= |Ship notes=Source: [http://www.miramarshipindex.org.nz/ship/show?nameid=180002&shipid=75917 Miramar Ship Information Database, Record No. 5185985] }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Header caption= |Ship class={{sclass2-|Tree|trawler|3|naval}} |Ship displacement=545 tons |Ship length={{convert|164|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|27|ft|8|in|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|11|ft|1|in|m|abbr=on}} (mean) |Ship draft= |Ship propulsion=One [[Triple expansion engine|triple expansion]] [[reciprocating engine]], 1 shaft, {{convert|850|ihp|abbr=on}} |Ship speed={{convert|12.25|kn}} |Ship range= |Ship complement=40 (as naval ship) |Ship crew=18 (as civilian ship) |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= *1 × [[QF 12 pounder 12 cwt naval gun|QF 12-pounder (76 mm) anti-aircraft gun]] *3 × [[Oerlikon 20 mm cannon|20 mm Oerlikon]] AA guns *30 × [[depth charge]]s |Ship armour= |Ship armor= |Ship aircraft= |Ship aircraft facilities= |Ship notes= }} |}
'''SS ''Walnut''''' was a refugee ship converted from a British [[minesweeping]] [[Tree-class trawler]] which carried Baltic refugees from Sweden to Canada in 1948. The refugees' arrival at [[Pier 21]] in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]] led to a controversy which played an important role in shaping Canada's postwar refugee policies.<ref name=raska>{{cite web |url=https://www.pier21.ca/blog/jan-raska/baltic-refugees-canadian-immigration-policy-and-the-arrival-of-ss-walnut |first=Jan |last=Raska |title=Baltic Refugees, Canadian Immigration Policy and the Arrival of SS Walnut |publisher=Canadian Museum of Immigration at Pier 21 |accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref>
Initially entering service during the [[Second World War]] as '''HMT ''Walnut''''', the trawler was sold for commercial purposes following the war. Converted for use as a cargo ship, the vessel retained the name ''Walnut'' until 1959 when sold and renamed '''''Keta'''''. The ship was [[Ship breaking|broken up]] in 1976.
==Design and description== Tree-class trawlers were designed to [[Displacement (ship)|displace]] 545 tons standard and 770 tons at deep load. They were {{convert|164|ft|m}} [[Length overall|long overall]] with a [[Beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|27|ft|8|in|m}} and a [[Draft (hull)|draught]] of {{convert|11|ft|1|in|m}}. They were powered by a one-cylinder boiler providing steam to one [[triple expansion engine|vertical triple expansion engine]]. This drove one shaft creating {{convert|850|ihp|kW|lk=in}} and giving the ship a maximum speed of {{convert|12.25|kn|lk=in}}. The ship could carry 183 tons of coal.<ref name=conway>Chesneau, p.66</ref>
The Tree class was armed with one [[QF 12-pounder 12 cwt naval gun|QF 12-pounder (76 mm)]] gun, three [[20 mm Oerlikon]] anti-aircraft guns and 30 [[depth charge]]s. The trawlers had a complement of 40.<ref name=conway/>
==Royal Navy service== ''Walnut'' was [[Keel laying|laid down]] on 15 June 1939 as HMT ''Walnut'' (T103) by [[Smiths Dock Company]] at [[South Bank, Middlesbrough]] with the yard number 1031, one of 20 {{sclass2-|Tree|trawler|1}}s built for the British [[Royal Navy]].<ref name=conway/><ref name=miramar>{{csr|register=MSI|id=5185958|shipname=Walnut |accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref> ''Walnut'' was [[Ship naming and launching|launched]] on 12 August 1939 and completed on 13 December 1939.<ref name=miramar/> ''Walnut'' belonged to a group of ten minesweepers commanded by New Zealanders in the 24th and 25th anti-submarine and minesweeping flotillas, protecting convoys on the east coast of Britain where they faced numerous German air and sea attacks. ''Walnut''{{'}}s commander, [[Gordon Bridson]], received the [[Distinguished Service Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Service Cross]] for his performance while in command of ''Walnut''.<ref name=Dennerly2000>{{cite web |last=Dennerly |first=P. Y. |date=2000 |url=http://www.dnzb.govt.nz/dnzb/default.asp?Find_Quick.asp?PersonEssay=5B41 |title=Bridson, Gordon 1909–1972 |work=Dictionary of New Zealand Biography |volume=5 |accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref> By the end of 1946, ''Walnut'' was one of only two Tree-class trawlers still in service with the Royal Navy.<ref>{{cite book |editor-first=Anthony |editor-last=Preston |title=Jane's Fighting Ships of World War II |pages=78 |location=New York |publisher=Military Press |date=1989}}</ref> Both were sold in 1948.
==Refugee ship== ''Walnut'' was first purchased by the Swedish firm Stem Olson and converted to a coastal cargo ship. In September 1948 the ship was purchased by a group of refugees from several Baltic countries who pooled their life savings to form a company called "Compania Maritima Walnut S/A".<ref name=freedom>{{cite web |url=http://www.walnutship1948.ca/Walnut_ship_Estonian_Refugees_statistics.htm |title=Ship Statistics |website=SS Walnut 1948 - Voyaged to Freedom |accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref> The refugees had fled to Sweden after the Soviet occupation of the Baltic republics. The uncertainty of their status in Sweden and fears that they would be forcibly repatriated to the [[Soviet]]s led the refugees to search for ships which could take them to another country that might offer secure refuge. ''Walnut'' was registered under the Panama flag to avoid Swedish restrictions on passenger capacity and hastily converted to accommodate 200 passengers.
The ship sailed from [[Gothenburg]], Sweden on 13 November 1948 and stopped at [[Lysekil]], Sweden to complete the embarkation of passengers and supplies before a final departure on November 17.<ref name=freedom/> ''Walnut'' carried 347 passengers, mostly [[Estonia]]ns, but also Latvians, Lithuanians, Finns, Austrians, and Polish refugees.<ref name=raska/> ''Walnut'' stopped at [[Sligo]], Ireland to load coal before crossing the Atlantic. Designed for a civilian crew of 18 or a military crew of 40, the 347 passengers endured a difficult voyage in bad weather, battling leaks and seasickness but arrived safely at [[Sydney, Nova Scotia]] on 10 December where food and more coal were taken aboard before the ship resumed its voyage for the Canadian immigration terminal at [[Pier 21]] in Halifax, Nova Scotia.<ref>{{cite news |title=347 Refugees Fleeing Reds Believed on Way to Halifax |work=Halifax Mail |date=11 December 1948}}</ref>
==Canadian reaction== ''Walnut'' arrived at Halifax on 13 December. The small ship was among the smallest to ever call at the [[Pier 21]] immigration terminal, dwarfed by the giant [[Four funnel liner|four stacker]] [[RMS Aquitania]] which arrived at the same pier a few days later with 1,656 passengers.<ref>"Aquitania Lands 1,656 Passengers", ''The Halifax Mail'', Dec. 28, 1948, p. 3</ref> ''Walnut'' presented Halifax immigration officials with a dilemma. The passengers aboard had arrived in Canada without permission or clearance, one of a series of small ships carrying Baltic refugees, nicknamed "The Viking Ships", which suddenly arrived in Canada in the fall of 1948. Others included the ships ''Gladstone'', ''Sarabande'', ''Parnu'', ''Ostervag'', ''Capry'', and ''Amanda''. ''Walnut'' had the largest number of aboard and became the focus of public and official attention over the fate of the refugees. The Baltic refugees had tried to come to Canada through official channels but were frustrated by the long delay and barriers in Canada's immigration system which left them vulnerable to a forced return to the Soviet controlled Baltic republics. ''Walnut''{{'}}s passengers were detained, some at Halifax's Rockhead prison and others in the detention quarters at the Pier 21 immigration terminal.
However the plight of the refugees soon attracted considerable support, especially as they arrived close to Christmas. The [[West End, Halifax|Halifax West End]] Baptist Church presented the refugees in detention with a radio for entertainment and organized a Christmas carol concert on December 21.<ref>"Gift radio Presented at Immigration", ''The Halifax Mail'', Dec. 22, 1948, p.3</ref> A variety of civic groups led by the mayor of Halifax [[John E. Ahern]] banded together to present a Christmas concert and gifts to the refugees on Christmas Eve. Local seamstresses assembled a costume to represent an Estonian version of Santa Claus, Youluvana, for the captain of ''Walnut'' to wear as he gave presents to all the children aboard including silver dollars given the youngest child; the oldest refugee and the mother of the largest family meant to mark the "start of the wealth they would accumulate when they were allowed to settle in Canada".<ref>"Christmas Made Happy for Baltic Refugee Children", ''The Halifax Mail'', Dec. 27, 1948, p.3</ref>
Public pressure and widespread press attention made Canadian immigration officials investigate and consider each passenger’s background. In the end, Canada admitted all but two passengers from ''Walnut'', waiving the immigration restrictions of the time by issuing an [[Order in Council]] for each individual. In January 1949, the ''Walnut'' refugees held a farewell party with local immigration officials before leaving by train to settle in various regions of Canada. The arrival of the small ex-warship had pushed Canadian immigration officials to change Canadian immigration intervention and interception policies.<ref name=raska/>
==Later career== After ''Walnut''{{'}}s arrival in Halifax, the ship was detained at the French Cable Wharf in [[Dartmouth, Nova Scotia]]. The ship was sold by auction to pay for expenses from the voyage. During the protracted legal process surrounding her refugee passengers, the ship was stripped of its brass fittings by thieves and scuttled in shallow water in Dartmouth. The ship was sold at another auction in 1951 and rebuilt by the Quebec firm Borromee Verreault. ''Walnut'' was renamed ''Keta'' and worked on the [[St. Lawrence River]] and Canadian Arctic until the ship was scrapped in 1975.<ref name=freedom/>
==Commemoration== Passengers who arrived aboard Walnut and their families remained in contact and organized several re-unions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.walnutship1948.ca/Walnut_Ship_Estonian_Refugees_Passenger_Anniversaries.htm |title=Reunions |website=SS Walnut 1948 - Voyaged to Freedom |accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref> Many shared photographs to remember their journey which were featured in a display at the Pier 21 museum which opened in the former immigration terminal in 1999.<ref>{{cite book |first=Lynda |last=Mannik |title=Photography, Memory and Refugee Identity: The Voyage of the SS Walnut, 1948 |publisher=UBC Press |date=2013 |pages=83–4}}</ref> When the Pier 21 museum reopened as national museum, the [[Canadian Museum of Immigration at Pier 21]] in 2014, ''Walnut'' was featured in an interactive video which presents visitors with the 1948 ''Walnut'' controversy and asks them how they would have responded.
==References==
===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}}
===Sources=== * {{cite book |editor-last=Chesneau |editor-first=Roger |date=1980 |title=Conway's All the World's Fighting Ships 1922—1946 |publisher=Conway Maritime Press |location=Greenwich, UK |isbn=0-85177-146-7}}
{{Tree class trawler}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Walnut}} [[Category:Tree-class trawlers]] [[Category:World War II patrol vessels of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:International maritime incidents]] [[Category:1939 ships]] [[Category:History of immigration to Canada]] [[Category:History of the Baltic states]] [[Category:Refugees in Canada]]

revision.comment: /* The Genesis Report */ template
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Tone|date=May 2009}} {{Infobox event | title = Saipan incident | participants = [[Roy Keane]], [[Mick McCarthy]], [[Bertie Ahern]], [[Republic of Ireland|Irish society]] | type = [[Industrial relations]] | cause = Differential perspectives on [[Football Association of Ireland|FAI]] policy | outcome = Dismissal of [[Roy Keane]], Prolonged national self-examination | inquiries = [[Football Association of Ireland|FAI]] Genesis Report | litigation = None | place = [[Saipan|Saipan, Northern Mariana Islands]] | date = May, 2002 }}
The '''Saipan incident''' was a public quarrel in May 2002 between [[Republic of Ireland national football team]]'s [[captain (association football)|captain]] [[Roy Keane]] and [[manager (football)|manager]] [[Mick McCarthy]] when the team was preparing in [[Saipan]] for its matches in [[Japan]] in the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]]. It resulted in Keane, a key player, being sent home from the squad. The incident divided public opinion in Ireland regarding who was to blame.
==Background== [[File:Roy Keane cropped.jpg|thumb|right|Roy Keane signing autographs in 2005.]] Prior to the incident, Keane was captain of the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Irish national team]]; since his senior debut under [[Jack Charlton]] and then-captain McCarthy, Keane had perceived problems with the preparations of the Irish side. He regarded the [[Football Association of Ireland]] (FAI)'s preparations as unprofessional and challenged both Charlton and McCarthy in a number of notable incidents.<ref>Keane, Roy; Dunphy, Eamon (2002). Keane: The Autobiography. Michael Joseph. {{ISBN|0-7181-4554-2}}. p. 244</ref>
Among Keane's issues with Irish management were the conditions of the camp, travel arrangements (which made the players sit in second class seats on flights, while FAI officials sat in first class), strategy, expectations, diet, and McCarthy's competence. In his autobiography, Keane said that before a [[2002 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] qualifier away versus the Netherlands, the Irish players were eating cheesy sandwiches because the more suitable pre-match meal of pasta was not available.<ref>[http://www.soccer-ireland.com/saipan/roy-keane/sandwiches.htm ''Soccer-Ireland.com''] Saipan Incident Thesis</ref>
==World Cup preparation== The island of [[Saipan]] was selected by an FAI delegation as an initial base. From management's perspective the time was considered a period of relative rest and recreation at the end of a long season before moving to Japan to up the preparation levels for the tournament. Keane, on the other hand, who is reputed to have told [[Alex Ferguson]] that he was going to the World Cup "to win it", viewed it as a period of preparation for the World Cup Finals. He therefore became dissatisfied when facilities and general preparation did not match his expectations.
On 21 May Keane decided he was going home but subsequently changed his mind and stayed on.<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/archive/2002/0522/Pg022.html#Ar02201:0AA09020D1430C51500F016808935D0A43750A435D0B43751A929E1B42B51B42A01D42B517A37E1A639527A1EE2A62062AC2CF2D82E622240225F42142F4C044A4D844D4C045C4D86E44C370F4DB0A31500B71680B71500BF16819522E1B02451852FD1A131423832D2533442B928E2D42A61F640221B42140D4C04184D84184C242A4D7 ''Irish Times''] Archived Irish Times report on the incident.</ref>
==The media== Irish broadcaster [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] became aware of the developing row, as did several Irish newspapers. Because of its isolated location, there were certain stories circulating about the event which were all critical of Keane. The ''[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]'' newspaper had been a harsh critic of Keane for months in the run up to the competition. This included persistent allegations about Keane's commitment to the Irish team.
Contrary to what many believe, that is, that Keane gave an interview to leading sports journalist [[Tom Humphries]] of the Irish broadsheet daily newspaper ''[[The Irish Times]]'', Keane had actually originally agreed to give the interview to [[Paul Kimmage]] of ''[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|The Sunday Independent]]''. Kimmage then agreed to let Tom Humphries join in on the interview, but made him promise not to print the article until after Kimmages column on Sunday. Humphries reneged on the deal and in retrospect this proved to be a major scoop for the ''Irish Times''. In the article, Keane listed the events and concerns which had led him to decide to leave the team. This article included details and references to the preparations that had been set in place for the Irish team. This would be an indirect implication that the event was organized as a junket for FAI officialdom. The article was seen as a direct affront to the authority of the Irish manager, and the competence of the FAI.
==The incident== The ''Irish Times'' article increased tensions greatly. McCarthy decided to question Keane about the article. In a team meeting McCarthy held up a copy of the article and asked ''"What's this all about?"'', and an argument started. McCarthy then accused Keane of faking injury when Ireland were playing Iran in the second leg of the play off. Keane then unleashed a stinging verbal tirade against McCarthy: ''"Mick, you're a liar … you're a fucking wanker. I didn't rate you as a player, I don't rate you as a manager, and I don't rate you as a person. You're a fucking wanker and you can stick your World Cup up your arse. The only reason I have any dealings with you is that somehow you are the manager of my country! You can stick it up your bollocks."''<ref>{{cite news |url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/comment/story/0,9753,1606114,00.html |title=10 classic Roy Keane rants |work=Guardian football | location=London | date=24 August 2006 | accessdate=21 April 2010}}</ref> Mick McCarthy then held a press conference announcing that he had sent Keane home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2002/0523/26016-worldcup/|title=McCarthy sends Keane home from World Cup|date=23 May 2002|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Niall Quinn]] observed in his autobiography that ''"Roy Keane's 10-minute oration [against Mick McCarthy] … was clinical, fierce, earth-shattering to the person on the end of it and it ultimately caused a huge controversy in Irish society."'' But at the same time, he was also critical of Keane's stance, saying that ''"[He] left us in Saipan, not the other way round. And he punished himself more than any of us by not coming back."''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sunderland/5281188.stm |title=The Odd Couple |work=BBC Sport | date=27 August 2006 | accessdate=31 December 2009}}</ref>
None of his team-mates voiced support for Keane during the meeting, though some later expressed their support to him privately. Keane mentioned in his autobiography that [[Gary Breen]] and [[David Connolly]] visited his room. Senior players [[Steve Staunton]] and [[Niall Quinn]] seemed to take the side of McCarthy, and the FAI, in the argument that followed. Staunton was the most loyal to the FAI line of the argument. He was later given the captaincy in Keane's absence.<ref>{{citeweb|url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/may/01/world-cup-moments-roy-keane-ireland-exit|title= World Cup: 25 stunning moments ... No13: Roy Keane walks out on Ireland|date=1 May 2014|work=Guardian|accessdate=2 April 2015}}</ref>
==Consequences== Despite the efforts of the media and [[Taoiseach]] [[Bertie Ahern]], Keane and McCarthy failed to resolve the conflict and Keane missed the World Cup. Keane gave an interview concerning the controversy to RTÉ and when asked if it was possible to go back he did not deny that he might. The Irish football team were defeated in a penalty shootout by [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in the second round.
==The Genesis Report== The FAI commissioned a report from external consultants Genesis, into its World Cup preparations. The "Genesis Report" agreed with many of Keane's criticisms, finding that the FAI structure was not conducive to good planning and making a range of recommendations.<ref>http://foot.ie/inc/pdf/genesis.pdf</ref> The complete report was never published for legal reasons.{{Explain|date=September 2018}} Brendan Menton resigned as FAI General Secretary at this time, and the media linked the two events, though Menton denied this.
==McCarthy's departure== Roy Keane stated that he would not play again for Ireland under McCarthy, and in his autobiography even said that his former national team coach could 'rot in hell'. McCarthy continued as national team manager and Ireland then played [[Russia national football team|Russia]] in a [[2004 UEFA European Football Championship qualifying|qualifying match]] for the [[UEFA European Football Championship|European Championship]]. Ireland lost to a badly resourced Russian team 4–2, who had played badly in the World Cup. This was followed by a "booing" episode in Ireland's next qualifier against [[Switzerland]], with many fans blaming McCarthy. Ireland lost the game 2–1 at Lansdowne Road. In the face of rebellion on the terraces, a decrease in support for the national team, and consequent declining attendance revenues, the FAI decided to remove McCarthy. Ireland then failed to qualify for any major tournament until 2011, when after beating Estonia they qualified for the [[UEFA Euro 2012|2012 European Championships]]. The appointment of [[Brian Kerr (Irish football manager)|Brian Kerr]] as team manager in 2003 led to Keane's return to international football on 27 May 2004, in a friendly match against [[Romania national football team|Romania]] at [[Lansdowne Road]]. He played his final international game the following year, having been capped 67 times for the nation since 1991. He retired from playing at club level in 2006.
==Settling differences== As of November 2006, Keane appeared to have mended the fences with McCarthy when the two men settled their differences via a phone call ahead of a match between McCarthy's [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] and Keane's [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]]. The handshake between the two men received considerable media attention. In April 2007, the managers again met in another match, and Keane praised McCarthy for his work in Sunderland previous to Keane's tenure there.
In December 2013, Keane, speaking in an [[ITV4]] documentary, admitted his regret at missing out on the 2002 World Cup and said that he should have put his personal issues with McCarthy to one side for the sake of the country, saying "To play in the World Cup. It would have been nice to play, A lot of people were disappointed, particularly my family."<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/keane-missing-2002-world-cup-is-biggest-regret-of-my-career-29827520.html|title= Keane: Missing 2002 World Cup is biggest regret of my career|date=11 December 2013|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=11 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thescore.ie/13-things-learned-keane-vieira-documentary-1216596-Dec2013/ |title=13 things we learned from the Roy Keane-Patrick Vieira documentary |date=11 December 2013 |work=The Score |accessdate=11 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213023801/http://www.thescore.ie/13-things-learned-keane-vieira-documentary-1216596-Dec2013/ |archivedate=13 December 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==Popular culture== The incident was so divisive that it was called a "civil war" for Ireland. The ''Irish Times'' later wrote that "[m]ost people have ... a story of a split between families, between friends, between work colleagues."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2012/0512/1224315983865.html?via=mr | title=How war in the Pacific brought madness to these shores | work=Irish Times | date=12 May 2012 | accessdate=12 May 2012 | author=Clerkin, Malachy}}</ref> In 2005, a musical comedy play parodying the incident and its key players, ''[[I, Keano]]'', opened in Dublin. The play, written by [[Arthur Mathews (writer)|Arthur Mathews]], [[Michael Nugent]], and [[Paul Woodfull]], represented the incident as a mock-epic melodrama about a Roman legion preparing for war. Keane attended a performance of the show,<ref>[http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2005/07/26/story963485323.asp Hundreds Queue for Tickets on Roy's Home Turf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929152925/http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2005/07/26/story963485323.asp |date=29 September 2007 }} Niamh Hennessy, ''Irish Examiner'', 26 July 2005</ref> which ran in Dublin until May 2008.
In an echo of the incident, three main cast members, including [[Mario Rosenstock]], who portrayed "Keano" (the play's version of Roy Keane), left the show early in its first run, leading to media articles about [[life imitating art]] [[Mimesis|imitating life]].<ref>Art Imitates Life as Hit ''I, Keano'' Camp Splits. ''[[Evening Herald]]'', 25 Feb 2005</ref><ref>New Scandal For Roy Keane Musical. Brian Logan, ''[[The Guardian]]'', 3 March 2005</ref><ref>[http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2005/12/24/story515665173.asp Lasting Impression] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817162743/http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2005/12/24/story515665173.asp |date=17 August 2009 }} Interview with Mario Rosenstock, ''Irish Examiner'', 24 December 2005</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.soccer-ireland.com/saipan/index.htm Article and Analysis of the incident]
{{Republic of Ireland national football team}}
[[Category:Association football controversies]] [[Category:Republic of Ireland at the 2002 FIFA World Cup]] [[Category:Saipan]] [[Category:2002 controversies]] [[Category:2002 in the Northern Mariana Islands]] [[Category:May 2002 events]]

{{Infobox film festival | name = San Francisco Jewish Film Festival | logo = | logo_alt = | logo_size = | image = | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = | opening = | closing = | location = [[San Francisco]], [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]], [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[San Rafael, California|San Rafael]], and [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], [[California]] | predecessor = | founded = 1980 | disestablished = | successor = | awardsreceived = | awards = | films = | directors = | producers = | writers = | starring = | host = | number = | date = | language = | website = [https://jfi.org/film-festival jfi.org] | chronology = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''San Francisco Jewish Film Festival''' is the oldest Jewish film festival in the world, and currently the largest with a 2016 attendance figure of 40,000 at screenings in San Francisco, Berkeley, Oakland, San Rafael, and Palo Alto.<ref>{{cite web|title=AJFF Slips to No. 2|url=http://atlantajewishtimes.com/2016/08/ajff-slips-no-2/|website=Atlanta Jewish Times|publisher=Jewish Times|accessdate=February 6, 2017}}</ref> The three-week summer festival is held in [[San Francisco]], [[California]], usually at the [[Castro Theater]] in San Francisco and other cinemas in San Francisco, [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]], [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[San Rafael, California|San Rafael]], and [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], and features contemporary and classic independent Jewish film from around the world. In 2015, the organization re-branded itself as the Jewish Film Institute, retaining the name "San Francisco Jewish Film Festival" for the annual film festival.
The San Francisco Jewish Film Festival also maintains an online archive of Jewish film,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfjff.org/film/search |title=Search |publisher=San Francisco Jewish Film Festival |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627031607/http://www.sfjff.org/film/search |archivedate=2013-06-27 |df= }}</ref> and holds individual film screenings throughout the year.
The festival was first held at the [[Roxie Theater]] in San Francisco in 1980. The current executive director is Lexi Leban and the program director is Jay Rosenblatt.
In 2009, the officials in charge of the event were criticized for the decision to the screen of a film about [[International Solidarity Movement|ISM]] activist [[Rachel Corrie]]. Writing in the [[J. (newspaper)|N. California JWeekly,]] Dan Pine noted "If the Academy handed out an Oscar for community turmoil, the Rachel Corrie flap at this year’s San Francisco Jewish Film Festival would win handily." <ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/39342/rachel-inferno-gets-even-hotter-for-s.f.-festival/|title=‘Rachel’ inferno gets even hotter for S.F. festival {{!}} j. the Jewish news weekly of Northern California|last=pine|first=dan|website=www.jweekly.com|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> Pine reported that some Jewish community members said that festival organizers "crossed a line into overtly anti-Israel propaganda" and that "Corrie, and now her parents, have worked to ostracize and delegitimize Israel." <ref name=":0" /> In a statement, festival Executive Director Peter Stein apologized "for not fully considering how upsetting this program might be." At the same time, the festival did not back down from its decision to screen the film.<ref name=":0" />
The [http://sfjff36.jfi.org/festival-guide/ 36th festival] was held between July 21 and August 7, 2016, in five locations around the Bay Area. The featured films included "Germans & Jews", and Director Janina Quint was scheduled to attended the screening.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} The 37th festival took place July 20 to August 6, 2017, in the same five Bay Area locations as previous years.<ref name="Article in J. Weekly">[https://www.jweekly.com/2017/06/07/sf-jewish-film-fest-highlights-women-directors-on-opening-closing-nights/ Article in ''J. Weekly'']</ref> The opening and closing films, ''Keep the Change'' and ''[[Bombshell: The Hedy Lamarr Story]]'', were both directed by women.<ref name="Article in J. Weekly"/>
The 38th festival took place July 19 to August 5, 2018.<ref>[https://jfi.org/sf-jewish-film-festival SF Jewish Film Festival website]</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.sfjff.org San Francisco Jewish Film Festival] *[http://jewishfilminstitute.org/ Jewish Film Institute] *[https://www.youtube.com/user/SFJewishFilmFestival SF Jewish Film Festival Youtube Channel] *[https://twitter.com/jewishfilmnews SF Jewish Film Festival on Twitter]
{{Jewish film festivals}}

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Sistema Nacional de Protección Civil, Prevención y Mitigación de Desastres |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = August 31, 2005 |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |jurisdiction = [[Government of El Salvador]] |headquarters = 15 Av. Norte y 9a C. Poniente
Torre del Ministerio de Gobernación
San Salvador |telephone = +503 2281-0888 |employees = |budget = |chief1_name = Jorge Antonio Meléndez |chief1_position = General Director |chief2_name = Baudilio Ventura Portillo |chief2_position = Sub-director |agency_type = |parent_agency = Ministry of the Interior |child1_agency = |website = [http://www.proteccioncivil.gob.sv/ www.proteccioncivil.gob.sv] |footnotes = }} The '''National Civil Defence System for Disaster Prevention and Mitigation''' of [[El Salvador]] (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]: Sistema Nacional de Protección Civil, Prevención y Mitigación de Desastres), commonly known as "Protección Civil", is an entity created to prevent disasters or reduce their impact on society, and coordinate [[disaster relief]] efforts.{{cite web |author= |title=Decreto Legislativo 777 Ley de protección civil, prevención y mitigación de desastres |url=http://www.csj.gob.sv/leyes.nsf/0/491cf0078f83abc50625708c007480b6?OpenDocument&Click= |publisher=Corte Suprema de Justica |date=2005-08-31 |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723055657/http://www.csj.gob.sv/leyes.nsf/0/491cf0078f83abc50625708c007480b6?OpenDocument&Click= |archivedate=2011-07-23 |df= }} The Salvadoran Civil Defence System is part of a Central American network of governmental disaster relief agencies known as the [[Coordination Center for the Prevention of Natural Disasters in Central America]] (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]: Centro de Coordinación para la Prevención de los Desastres Naturales en América Central (CEPREDENAC)). CEPREDENAC was created in the context of the [[Central American Integration System|Central American Integration System (SICA)]]. {{cite web |author= |title=Centro de Coordinación para la Prevención de Desastres Naturales en America Central (CEPREDENAC) |url=http://www.sica.int/busqueda/Informaci%C3%B3n%20Entidades.aspx?IDItem=466&IDCat=29&IdEnt=401 |publisher=sica.int |date= |accessdate= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.cepredenac.org/ Coordination Center for the Prevention of Natural Disasters in Central America (CEPREDENAC)] *[http://www.satcaweb.org/alertatemprana/inicio/alertatemprana.aspx SATCA Early warning system for Central America (Sistema de Alerta Temprana para Centroamérica (SATCA))] *[http://www.redhum.org/ Humanitarian Information Network for Latin America and the Caribbean (Red de Información Humanitaria para América Latina y el Caribe (Redhum))] {{DEFAULTSORT:Sistema Nacional De Proteccion Civil}} [[Category:Government of El Salvador]] [[Category:Disaster management]]

'''"Sniper"''' is a [[ballad]] written by [[Harry Chapin]] and first released on the album ''[[Sniper and Other Love Songs]]'' in 1972.
==Overview== The song, nearly 10 minutes long, is based on the shootings at the [[University of Texas tower shooting]] in 1966, with some fictional elements. The song does not name the actual [[sniper]], [[Charles Whitman]], or the location. The victims' names have also been changed.
Harry wrote this piece using three distinct "voices" for dramatic effect. Chapin sings all three voices. The first is the narrator, telling the story. The second is a variety of people reacting to the event, as if in response to news media questions. And the third voice is that of the Sniper himself, stating his fears, his motives, and his raw emotions. Throughout the song, the time signature changes several times, with variations in tempo, identifying and supporting the three different voices. The narrator begins by describing the Sniper climbing the stairs of the tower, "two bulky [[suitcase]]s hang[ing] from his hands," who then begins shooting at people on the streets below. We hear the public's response and descriptions of the Sniper by those who knew him. The narrator returns and this cycle begins again. Eventually the Sniper pours out his pain over the failed relationship between himself and his mother, who had ignored him as a child.
In the end, the sniper is killed by police officers who have climbed the tower. The sniper's last words – "I was, I am, and now I will be" – lend insight into the [[psychology]] of the sniper, who has been on a lifelong quest for [[self actualization]].
==External links== * [http://harrychapin.com/music/sniper.shtml Lyrics] * [http://blogcritics.org/i-will-be-the-horror-of/ "I Will Be": The Horror of Harry Chapin's "Sniper" -- Sean T. Collins] * [https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/harrychapin/albums/album/184584/review/5946314/sniper_and_other_love_songs Review of "Sniper And Other Love Songs"]
{{Harry Chapin}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=May 2018}} {{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=March 2014}}{{notability|Events|date=January 2014}} {{Orphan|date=March 2014}} }} {{Infobox music festival | music_festival_name = SwaraZankar Music Festival | image = | caption= | location = Violin Academy,
[[Pune]], [[Maharashtra]], [[India]] | years_active = 2009 - Present | founders = Violin Academy and Centre for Promotion of Music | dates = 10 to 12 January. | website = [http://swarzankar.org/Default.aspx Official site] }} '''Swarazankar Music Festival''' is an event organised by Violin Academy, Pune to present artists of all Gharanas and all types of instruments. It was started in Pune in 2009. ==The Event== The three-day festival started in 2009. Some of the renowned Hindustani classical music artistes perform at the event. SwaraZankar is a place to come and enjoy Indian Classical Music. The chief objective of its founder, pt. Atulkumar Upadhye - a noted violinist all over the world using only fingering without using meends or glides, characteristic on Indian Music, is to popularize Indian Classical Music. To create awareness for Indian Classical Music and to prepare strong audiences for future talents, SwaraZankar travels from city to city. currently, SwaraZankar has covered cities like Pune, Aurangabad, Nashik and Kolhapur, Mumbai, Jalgaon, Belgaum, Dharwad, Solapur, Nagpur, Ratnagiri and Pandharpur. To add into the list SwaraZankar will be conducting Swarazankar Indore, Bengaluru and Chennai too. All the top artists and Maestros like Pt. Hariprasad Chaurasia, Pt. Shivkumar Sharma, Pt. Vishwamohan Bhatt, Ashwini Bhide-Deshpande, Kaushiki Chakraborty, Pt. Anindo Chatterjee and many other excellent musicians have joined us in our cause and thus are a part of our family.[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/speednewsshow/11390007.cms Swar-Jhankar: A three day music festival Swar Jhankar got under way today] SwaraZankar, Swara means melodious voice and Zankar is sound of payal. ==See also== {{Portal|Indian classical music}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140113004248/http://swarzankar.org/ Official site] {{Hindustani Classical Music page end}} [[Category:Music festivals established in 2009]] [[Category:Hindustani classical music festivals]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2009]] [[Category:Culture of Pune]]

{{Infobox recurring event | name = The Scottish Short Film Festival | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_size = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | status = Active | genre = Short film festival | date = July | begins = | ends = | frequency = Annually | founded = 2012 | venue = {{unbulleted list | {{nowrap|[[Crowne Plaza Glasgow]]}} {{small|(2018-Present)}} | Bathgate Regal Community Theatre {{small|(2015-2017)}} | Howden Park Centre {{small|(2014)}} | The Grosvenor Cinema {{small|(2012)}} }} | location = [[Glasgow]] {{small|(2012, 2018-Present)}}
[[West Lothian]] {{small|(2014-2017)}} | coordinates = | country = Scotland | years_active = {{age|2012|12|02}} | established = | founder_name = Chris Young | last = | prev = | next = | participants = | attendance = | capacity = | area = | budget = | activity = | leader_name = | patron = | organised = | filing = | people = | member = | sponsor = | website = {{URL|http://www.scottishshortfilmfestival.com}} | footnotes = }} '''The Scottish Short Film Festival''' is an independent film festival which has taken place annually in Scotland since 2012. From 2012 to 2017, the festival was known as The Raptor Filmz Short Scottish Film Festival until the event was rebranded in 2018. [https://filmfreeway.com/ScottishShortFilmFestival Festival listing on Film Freeway] ==History and format== The festival was set up in 2012 by Scottish filmmaker Chris Young who is the company director of Raptor Filmz Ltd in [[West Lothian]]. The aim of the festival is to promote short Scottish films with a view of potentially setting up a distribution deal with filmmakers. The first festival took place in [[Glasgow]] at the [[Ashton Lane|Grosvenor Cinema]] and was hosted by Scottish actor [[Dave Anderson (actor)|David Anderson]].{{cite news|last=HARBINSON|first=EDDIE|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/local-news/bathgate-set-host-short-scottish-7285835|title=Bathgate set to host Short Scottish Film Festival|work=Daily Record|date=1 February 2016|access-date=1 February 2016}} With a desire to bring the festival closer to home, the festival was moved to the [[Howden House, West Lothian#Howden Park Centre|Howden Park Centre]] in [[Livingston, West Lothian|Livingston]] where the date of the festival was also moved to January 2014 rather than December 2013. In 2015, the festival found a new home at the [[Bathgate]] Regal Community Theatre which is operated by Scottish actor [[Scott Kyle]].{{cite news|last=VALENTE|first=ALLAN|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/local-news/bathgates-regal-theatre-host-annual-4983931|title=Bathgate's Regal Theatre to host annual Short Scottish Film Festival|work=Daily Record|date=15 January 2015|access-date=15 January 2015}} Speaking of the Regal, festival curator Chris Young said:{{quote|"I think we’ve found our home with the Regal. It’s a great historic venue, with friendly staff, brilliant equipment, and a fantastic audience.."}} The festival consists of awards for films and individual prizes. The awards are selected by jury with an audience choice award being decided by visitors of the festival. Jury members in the past have included actor [[Declan Michael Laird]] and film editor [[Chris Quick]].{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishshortfilmfestival.com/apps/blog/show/45156573-chris-quick-steps-down-as-judge|title=Chris Quick Steps Down As Judge|author=|date=|work=The Scottish Short Film Festival|access-date=6 January 2018}} In 2018, it was announced that Ross Miller, the film critic for [[The National (Scotland)|The National]] newspaper would join the judging panel. On 30 July 2017, it was announced that the festival would return in 2018 but under the new name of The Scottish Short Film Festival. The [[Centre for Contemporary Arts]] in Glasgow was due to host the 2018 festival[https://www.cca-glasgow.com/programme/the-scottish-short-film-festival-2018 Festival listing on Centre of Contemporary Arts page] but due to the fire at the [[Glasgow School of Art]], the venue was forced to close. It was announced on the festivals twitter account that the [[Crowne Plaza Glasgow]] would take over as host. ==Festival award winners== List of winners and nominees of the festival.{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishshortfilmfestival.com/winners|title=Scottish Short Film Festival Winners|author=|date=|work=Scottish Short Film Festival|access-date=8 March 2017}} ===2012 winners=== {| class="wikitable" |- !
